page.title: A Storm in the Rocky Mountains, Mt. Rosalie

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = A Storm in the Rocky Mountains, Mt. Rosalie | image_file = Albert Bierstadt - A Storm in the Rocky Mountains, Mt. Rosalie - Google Art Project.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 350px | alt = Rocky Mountains beneath a thunderstorm | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | artist = [[Albert Bierstadt]] | year = {{Start date|1866}} | height_metric = 210.8 | width_metric = 361.3 | height_imperial = 83 | width_imperial = 142.25 | city = [[Brooklyn]] | museum = [[Brooklyn Museum]] | url = {{URL|1=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/1558/ |2=Collections: American Art}} }} '''''A Storm in the Rocky Mountains, Mt. Rosalie''''' is an 1866 landscape oil painting by [[German American|German-American]] painter [[Albert Bierstadt]] that was inspired by sketches created on an 1863 expedition.
Bierstadt traveled to the [[Southern Rocky Mountains|Colorado Rocky Mountains]] where he was taken up to the Chicago Lakes beneath [[Mount Evans]]. The painting is named after Bierstadt's mistress and, at the time, his friend's wife, Rosalie Osborne Ludlow. The painting, measuring at {{convert|210.8|xx|361.3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}, is exhibited at the [[Brooklyn Museum]], who acquired it in 1976.<!--citation needed, though see accession number-->
==Background== [[File:The Rocky Mountains, Lander's Peak (Albert Bierstadt), 1863 (oil on linen - scan).jpg|thumb|left|''The Rocky Mountains, Lander's Peak'', 1863. This smaller version was painted from sketches made during Bierstadt's 1859 expedition.]] By the mid-19th century, the U.S. Government had begun sending surveying expeditions into the newly incorporated territories<ref name=wilton229/> of the [[American West]].<ref name=schmidt>Schmidt 2007.</ref> Albert Bierstadt ventured on at least two of these expeditions, which, along with other trips in the West, would inspire an incredible amount of his creative output.<ref name=64hendricks333>Hendricks 1964, p. 333.</ref> On his first expedition in 1859, he joined U.S. explorer [[Frederick W. Lander]], taking photographs of Native Americans<ref name=wilton229/> and painting field sketches of the landscape.<ref name=palmquist110>Palmquist and Kailbourn 2000, p. 110.</ref> They traveled through Kansas, Nebraska,<ref name=wilton229>Wilton and Barringer 2002, p. 229.</ref> and into the [[Wind River Range]] of the Rocky Mountains in Wyoming. This expedition resulted in paintings such as ''On the Sweetwater Near the Devil's Gate, Nebraska'';<ref name=64hendricks336>Hendricks 1964, p. 336.</ref> ''Sunset Light, Wind River Range of the Rocky Mountains''; ''Thunderstorm in the Rockies'';<ref name=64hendricks338>Hendricks 1964, p. 338.</ref> and most notably, two works similarly titled ''[[The Rocky Mountains, Lander's Peak]]''.<ref name=wilton230>Wilton and Barringer 2002, pp. 230.</ref>
''A Storm in the Rocky Mountains, Mt. Rosalie'' was born from sketches created during his second expedition to the West in 1863. The voyage would take Bierstadt to the Colorado and Wyoming Rocky Mountains, then on to Salt Lake City, Utah, and into California, with stops at Lake Tahoe,<ref name=64hendricks344>Hendricks 1964, p. 344</ref> San Francisco, and Yosemite.<ref name=64hendricks345>Hendricks 1964, p. 345.</ref> The expedition ended in Oregon by November 1863. After a journey totaling eight months, both Ludlow and Bierstadt returned to New York on 17 December.<ref name=64hendricks348>Hendricks 1964, p. 348.</ref>
==To the Rocky Mountains== Bierstadt desired to return to the West, "in search of a subject for a great Rocky Mountain picture",<ref name=byers237>Byers 1890, p. 237.</ref> so in April 1863,<ref name=64hendricks339>Hendricks 1964, p. 339.</ref> he departed [[New York (state)|New York]] with his friend and explorer, [[Fitz Hugh Ludlow]]<ref name=64hendricks339/> and two other gentlemen.<ref name=75hendricks116>Hendricks 1975, p. 116.</ref> They met Ludlow's wife, [[Rosalie Osborne]], in [[St. Louis]], Missouri,<ref name=75hendricks118>Hendricks 1975, p. 118.</ref> who accompanied them as far as Atchison, Kansas,<ref name=64ludlow>Ludlow 1864.</ref> the starting point for the [[Overland Trail]] stagecoach.<ref name=70ludlow2>Ludlow 1870, p. 2.</ref> [[File:Emigrants Crossing the Plains, or The Oregon Trail (Albert Bierstadt), 1869.jpg|thumb|right|''Emigrants Crossing the Plains'', 1869. This painting was likely inspired by the 1863 expedition.]] As they proceeded into and through Nebraska, Bierstadt would continuously sketch the land, weather, animals, and people around him. During this time, their party passed a fifty-[[wagon train]] of German emigrants who were headed to Oregon.<ref name=70ludlow110>Ludlow 1870, pp. 110–111.</ref> This event most likely inspired several paintings of the [[Oregon Trail]], including ''Emigrants Crossing the Plains'' and ''The Oregon Trail''.<ref name=64hendricks341>Hendricks 1964, p. 341.</ref> It was also during this trip through Nebraska that Bierstadt produced a series of sketches titled ''The Last of the Buffalo'', which were possibly referenced later on for his 1888 painting of the same name.<ref name=64hendricks342>Hendricks 1964, p. 342.</ref>
While still in the plains, the party stopped at a ranch to enjoy a buffalo hunt. Although Bierstadt did not participate,<ref name=70ludlow62>Ludlow 1870, p. 62.</ref> he was excited to paint the hunted animals. One of the men had wounded a bull and called to Ludlow to fetch Bierstadt. Ludlow described Bierstadt's set-up: "[Bierstadt] leapt from the buggy; out came the materials of success following him, and in a trifle over three minutes from his first halt, the big blue umbrella was pointed and pitched, and he sat under it on his camp-stool, with his color-box on his knees, his brush and palette in hand, and a clean board pinned in the cover of his color-box."<ref name=70ludlow67>Ludlow 1870, p. 67.</ref> Ludlow and two other men taunted the bull so "that [Bierstadt] may see him in action."<ref name=70ludlow68>Ludlow 1870, p. 68.</ref>
The party continued through Nebraska, before following the [[South Platte River]] toward Denver, Colorado.<ref name=70ludlow119>Ludlow 1870, p. 119.</ref> It was just after dawn when the expedition driver pointed westward and said, "There are the Rocky Mountains".<ref name=70ludlow130>Ludlow 1870, p. 130.</ref> Ludlow described his first view of the mountain range: "[T]o see an exquisite marine ghost appear, almost evanescent in its faint azure, but still a literal existence which had been called up from the deeps and laid to rest with infinite delicacy and difficulty, then you will form some conception of the first view of the Rocky Mountains."<ref name=70ludlow130131>Ludlow 1870, pp. 130–131.</ref>
===Colorado Springs=== [[File:Ambulance wagon on the Bull Run battlefield, 1861 (crop).jpg|thumb|right|An example of an ambulance wagon from 1861.]] Ludlow and Bierstadt's party rested in Denver for several days before deciding on a spontaneous 70-mile diversion to the south to visit the base of [[Pike's Peak]] and the [[Garden of the Gods]] near [[Old Colorado City]]<ref name=70ludlow139/> (now a part of modern-day [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]]). The journey would not have been possible because they lacked suitable vehicles,<ref name=64ludlow/> but [[John Evans (governor)|Governor John Evans]] kindly lent the expedition his ambulance wagon and "a pair of stout serviceable" horses. Bierstadt rode with his color-box alongside the guide, following the ambulance in a [[buckboard]] pulled by a single horse. On 10 June, the six-person party set off after breakfast.<ref name=70ludlow139>Ludlow 1870, p.139.</ref>
Thirty miles into their journey, they arrived at [[Castle Rock, Colorado|Castle Rock]], "a peculiar hill of the butte kind, a single cone, rising abrupt and solitary out of the level plain to the height of about four hundred feet".<ref name=70ludlow154>Ludlow 1870, p. 154.</ref> Ludlow and another man hiked to the top, describing it as "the quietest, sunniest, most satisfying mount of vision we had yet climbed." Bierstadt stopped long enough to sketch the butte before continuing his way south.<ref name=70ludlow155>Ludlow 1870, pp. 155–156.</ref>
The expedition spent three days<ref name=70ludlow176>Ludlow 1870, p. 176.</ref> at the base of Pike's Peak to explore the Fontaine qui Bouille (now called [[Fountain Creek]]), which allowed the men to bathe<ref name=70ludlow174>Ludlow 1870, p. 174.</ref> before beginning their work, making studies and collecting samples of the local geology.<ref name=70ludlow175>Ludlow 1870, pp. 175–176.</ref> On reaching the actual springs, the men compared the tastes of each spring, created lemon-flavored soda, and bottled pure spring water to later compare with city water.<ref name=70ludlow177>Ludlow 1870, p. 177.</ref> The afternoon of their last day was spent in the Garden of the Gods.<ref name=70ludlow178>Ludlow 1870, p. 178.</ref> The men enjoyed squeezing into a narrow cavern and reaching "a vault about fifty feet long, ten feet high", which they examined by candlelight, and comparing the Garden's rock formations to recognizable shapes, including animals and "a statue of Liberty, standing by her escutcheon, with the usual [[Phrygian cap]] on her head."<ref name=70ludlow179>Ludlow 1870, p. 179.</ref> The men were so impressed by the landscape, that "[i]t was a great disappointment to some of our kind friends that our artist [Bierstadt] did not choose the Garden of the Gods for a 'big picture.' It was such an interesting place in nature that they could not understand its unavailability for art." Ludlow later surmised that, "however impressive it might be outdoors, [the scenery] was absolutely incommunicable by paint and canvas".<ref name=70ludlow180>Ludlow 1870, p. 180.</ref>
===Idaho Springs=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 250 | image1 = Bierstadt Albert Mountain Lake.jpg | caption1 = ''Mountain Lake'', possibly 1863. | image2 = Chicago Lake, near Georgetown (William Henry Jackson), 1873 (right crop).jpg | caption2 = ''Chicago Lake, near Georgetown'', 1873. Photographed by William H. Jackson. Mount Evans appears in the far back left. | image3 = Sketch for Storm in the Rocky Mountains (Albert Bierstadt), 1863?.jpg | caption3 = A sketch for ''Storm in the Rocky Mountains'', possibly created in 1863, and believed to be the "earliest conception of the painting".<ref name=75hendricks159>Hendricks 1975, p. 159.</ref> }} Upon their return to Denver, Bierstadt, still looking for a mountain subject, was referred to [[William N. Byers]],<ref name=byers237/> founder and editor of the ''[[Rocky Mountain News]]'',<ref name=64ludlow/> who considered himself "something of a mountain tramp". Byers knew the Chicago Lakes<ref name=wilton234>Wilton and Barringer 2002, p. 234.</ref> would impress the artist. Bierstadt separated from his expedition, and he and Byers rode a buckboard up to [[Idaho Springs]],<ref name=byers237/> located 30 miles west of Denver. Byers would later write, "There we secured saddle animals and two or three donkeys to pack our bedding, provisions, paint-boxes, etc."<ref name=byers237/> Despite the rainy weather, they headed south from Idaho Springs further into the mountains, with Byers in the lead and Bierstadt behind the pack animals. They followed Chicago Creek through "dense forest" until they emerged into a "beautiful little flower-decked meadow". Byers rode out of Bierstadt's line of sight so that he could witness the artist's first impression of the valley.<ref name=byers237/> {{quote|text=Bierstadt emerged leisurely. His enthusiasm was badly dampened, but the moment he caught the view, fatigue and hunger were forgotten. He said nothing, but his face was a picture of intense life and excitement. Taking in the view for a moment, he slid off his mule, glanced quickly to see where the jack was that carried his paint outfit, walked sideways to it and began fumbling at the lash-ropes, all the time keeping his eyes on the scene up the valley.<ref name=byers237238>Byers 1890, pp. 237–238.</ref>}} Bierstadt told his guide, "I must get a study in colors; it will take me fifteen minutes!" The weather, however deteriorated, was impressive, and the view in front of Bierstadt included storm clouds drifting low over "sharp pinnacles and spires and masses of broken granite". Rays of sunlight broke through the cloud, and flowing down a mountain were "ribbons of water from the last hard shower [...] reflecting back the sunshine." Byers patiently waited for his guest to complete his sketch. When finished, Bierstadt asked, "There, was I more than fifteen minutes?" to which Byers replied, "Yes, you were at work forty-five minutes by the watch!"<ref name=byers238>Byers 1890, p. 238.</ref>
After continuing to Lower Chicago Lake, Bierstadt crossed the valley to sketch the landscape from a different vantage.<ref name=byers238/> Over the duration of their stay, Bierstadt "worked industriously [...], making many sketches in pencil and studies in oil—these latter in order to get the colors and shade."<ref name=byers240/> One of these studies, ''Mountain Lake'',<ref name=artrenewal/> was painted on the periphery of Lower Chicago Lake, featuring Mount Spalding.<ref name=xmission/> [[William Henry Jackson]] would take a photograph of Lower Chicago Lake ten years later in nearly the same spot that Bierstadt painted his study.<ref name=usgsjackson/>
Byers took Bierstadt to Upper Chicago Lake before climbing "to the crest of the rim of the upper basin and to [[Summit Lake Park|Summit Lake]], and beyond that to the summit of the highest snowy peak in the group", which is both "the subject [in the painting]" and "is visible from the streets of Denver".<ref name=byers240>Byers 1890, p. 240.</ref> The peak was unnamed at the time, so Bierstadt christened it "Mount Rosalie", after Ludlow's wife. Byers believed Bierstadt had named the peak "after one of the loftiest summits of the Alps".<ref name=wilton234/><ref name=byers240/><ref name=75hendricks128>Hendricks 1975, p. 128.</ref>
Bierstadt and Byers's return trip to Denver was "uneventful"<ref name=byers240/> and Fitz Hugh Ludlow would get to look at Bierstadt's studies, which he later described as "some of the finest color studies he made along that [mountain] chain—among others an exquisite series of lakes on a mountain to whose very top he ascended with his color-box, a height of over 15,000 feet, or considerably taller than [[Mont Blanc]]."<ref name=64ludlow/> Ludlow marveled at the landscape sketches and their colors and especially of the main peak<ref name=64ludlow/> that Bierstadt had named: {{quote|text=That glorious roseate mountain stood nameless among the peaks in its virgin vail of snew [''sic'', "veil of snow"]; so Bierstadt, by right of first portrayal, baptized it after one far away from our sides, but very near and dear to our hearts—a gentle nature who had followed us clear to the verge of our Overland wanderings at Atchison, and parted from us bravely lest she should make our purpose fainter by seeming moved. Henceforth that shining peak is Monte Rosa.<ref name=64ludlow/>}} On 23 June 1863, Bierstadt and Byers left Denver to continue their journey to California. The expedition's two other men would meet up with them at a later point.<ref name=70ludlow194>Ludlow 1870, p. 194.</ref>
===Rosalie=== [[File:Rosalie Osborne Bierstadt, seated, unknown date, William Kurtz (restored).jpg|thumb|right|''Rosalie Osborne Bierstadt'', unknown date.]] By 1857, Fitz Hugh Ludlow had become a known [[hashish]] addict and the bestselling author of ''[[The Hasheesh Eater]]''. In 1859, he married Rosalie Osborne<ref name=75hendricks113>Hendricks 1975, p. 113.</ref> in her hometown of [[Waterville, New York|Waterville]], New York.<ref name=75hendricks115>Hendricks 1975, p. 115.</ref> Her mother had reservations about Ludlow,<ref name=75hendricks114>Hendricks 1975, p. 114.</ref> who continuously struggled with finances. At one point, Rosalie was forced to write at least one job inquiry for him in a letter that could have been construed as flirtatious.<ref name=75hendricks115116>Hendricks 1975, p. 115–116.</ref>
Bierstadt returned to his studio in [[state of New York|New York]] and, in 1866, completed his oil painting, one of many inspired by field sketches made during that trip.<ref name=palmquist111>Palmquist and Kailbourn 2000, p. 111.</ref> He named the painting after his mistress,{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} Rosalie Osborne, whom he had married on November 21, 1866.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}<!--ref name=75hendricks has date--> <!--to be expanded-->
==Description== The painting depicts Native American hunter/gatherers hunting deer in the foreground.{{r|brooklynmuseum}} A Native American encampment resides by a stream in the distance. The mountains are thrown into either sunlight or the darkness of a thunderstorm.<ref name=berman>Berman 2002.</ref> In order to increase its dramatic value, Bierstadt exaggerated the scale of the [[Rocky Mountains]].{{r|brooklynmuseum}}
Peering through a break in the clouds in the far distance is a snow-capped Mt. Rosalie, named after Bierstadt’s wife.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}<!--info is in book “American Sublime”-->
Upon its completion, the painting toured the United States for a year.{{r|brooklynmuseum}} On 7 February 1866, ''A Storm in the Rocky Mountains, Mount Rosalie'' exhibited for one day and evening at the Somerville Art Gallery in New York City as a benefit for the "Nursery and Child's Hospital".{{r|nytbenefit}}<!--raised $2,200 hendricks 1975-->

page.title: A View of Het Steen in the Early Morning

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox artwork/wikidata|onlysourced=yes|year={{circa}} 1636}} '''''A View of Het Steen in the Early Morning''''', '''''Château de Steen with Hunter''''' or '''''Het Steen''''' is a landscape painting by [[Rubens]], dating to around 1636.
It measures 131.2 cm by 229.2 cm and is now in the [[National Gallery, London|National Gallery]] in London.
A rare example of a work painted for the artist's own pleasure rather than for a commission, it shows a view of the [[Elewijt Castle|Het Steen]] estate near Brussels, which he had acquired in 1635, set in an early-morning autumn landscape. He had initially intended a much smaller painting focussing on the house, using three small oak planks, probably spares from his studio – as the concept developed, seventeen more panels were added.
It has influenced artists including [[John Constable]], during his period working for [[Sir George Beaumont, 7th Baronet|Sir George Beaumont]], who then owned the painting and later donated it to the National Gallery in 1823.
The painting features the first convincing depiction of a [[mackerel sky]].
==External links== *[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/peter-paul-rubens-a-view-of-het-steen-in-the-early-morning National Gallery catalogue entry]

page.title: Landscape with the Flight into Egypt (Carracci)

revision.comment: removed grandparent category of [[Category:Flight into Egypt in art]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image=Annibale Carracci 003.jpg | image_size=350px | title=Landscape with the Flight into Egypt | artist=Annibale Carracci | year=c. 1604 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=122 | width_metric=230 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Rome | museum=[[Galleria Doria Pamphilj]] }} '''''Landscape with the Flight into Egypt''''' is a painting by the [[Italy|Italian]] [[Baroque]] painter [[Annibale Carracci]]. Dating from c. 1604, it remains in the palace for which it was painted in [[Rome]] as part of the collection of the [[Galleria Doria Pamphilj]].
The painting, depicting the biblical New Testament event of the ''[[Flight into Egypt]]'', was commissioned in 1603 by Cardinal [[Pietro Aldobrandini]] for the family chapel in his palace in Rome, later known as [[Palazzo Doria Pamphilj]]. The commission includes six paintings in six [[lunette]]s, which were executed by Carracci and his pupils (including [[Francesco Albani]], [[Domenichino]] and [[Giovanni Lanfranco]]).<ref>Martin, 317</ref>
The work is frequently regarded as a key work in Baroque [[landscape painting]] and is the "most celebrated example" of the "new landscape style" Carracci developed in Rome of "carefully constructed landscape panoramas", according to [[Rudolf Wittkower]].<ref>Wittkower, 70</ref> For [[John Rupert Martin]] it is "the archetypal classical landscape, later to be emulated with variations by Domenichino, [[Nicolas Poussin|Poussin]] and [[Claude Lorrain|Claude]] ... the small scale of the figures in relation to the spacious natural setting at once establishes a new priority in which landscape takes first place and history second";<ref>Martin, 60</ref> though insofar as it is "new", that is for Italian painting, as such works had been common in Northern painting since [[Joachim Patinir]] began to use the same reversal of scale almost a century before. The journey of the [[Holy Family]] is echoed by other moving elements including the sheep, birds, cows and the camels on the ridge at left.<ref>Martin, 176</ref>
Wittkower sees in it "a heroic and aristocratic conception of Nature tamed and ennobled by the presence of man", as such works always contain a large man-made feature, here the castle "severely composed of horizontals and verticals" under which the party moves. They are placed at the meeting of two diagonals represented by the sheep and the river, "thus figures and buildings are intimately blended with the carefully arranged pattern of the landscape".<ref>Wittkower, 70</ref>
[[Kenneth Clark]] mentions the work as an example of the "ideal landscape" driven to promote itself in the [[hierarchy of genres]] by emulating (in the absence of much evidence of what classical landscape painting was like) an essentially literary vision, largely derived from the pastoral poems of [[Virgil]]: "the features of which it is composed must be chosen from nature, as poetic diction is chosen from ordinary speech, for their elegance, their ancient associations, and their faculty of harmonious combination. ''[[Ut pictura poesis]]''".<ref>Clark, 67</ref> Clark's praise of the work is noticeably faint, as it lacks the spirit he finds in [[Giorgione]] and Claude in the same tradition: "At their best, as in the lunettes in the Doria Gallery, Annibale Carracci's landscapes are admirable pieces of picture-making, in which agreeably stylized parts are built up into a harmonious whole. We recognize the science which has gone into the construction of the castle in the centre of the ''Flight into Egypt''... But in the end these eclectic landscapes are of interest only to historians".<ref>Clark, 74; see the rest of the chapter for more whole-hearted praise of Giorgione and Claude.</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==References== *[[Kenneth Clark|Clark, Kenneth]], ''Landscape into Art'', 1949, page refs to Penguin edn of 1961 * Martin, John Rupert, ''Baroque'', 1977 (1991 Penguin edn used), Allen Lane/Pelican/Penguin/Viking *[[Rudolf Wittkower|Wittkower, Rudolf]], ''Art and Architecture in Italy, 1600-1750'', Penguin/Yale History of Art, 3rd edition, 1973, {{ISBN|0-14-056116-1}} {{Annibale Carracci}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Flight into Egypt (Carracci)}} [[Category:1600s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Annibale Carracci]] [[Category:Collections of the Doria Pamphilj Gallery|Carracci]] [[Category:Flight into Egypt in art|Carracci]] [[Category:Landscape paintings]] [[Category:Sheep in art]]

{{Infobox Artwork |image_file=Utro v sosnovom lesu.jpg |image_size=300px |title=Morning in a Pine Forest |artist=[[Ivan Shishkin]], [[Konstantin Savitsky]] |year=1889 |medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] |height_metric=139 |width_metric=213 |height_imperial= |width_imperial= |metric_unit=cm |imperial_unit=in |museum = [[Tretyakov Gallery]] |city = [[Moscow]] }} The '''''Morning in a Pine Forest''''' ({{lang-ru|Утро в сосновом лесу}}) is a painting by [[Russia]]n artists [[Ivan Shishkin]] and [[Konstantin Savitsky]]. The bears were painted by Savitsky,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spbdnevnik.ru/?show=article&id=3460|format=|script-title=ru:Загадка картин Ивана Шишкина|publisher =Spbdnevnik.ru |author= |accessdate=2009-03-10|language=ru}}</ref> but the art collector [[Pavel Tretyakov]] effaced his signature, stating that "from idea until performance, everything discloses the painting manner and creative method peculiar just to Shishkin",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artclassic.edu.ru/catalog.asp?ob_no=19462&cat_ob_no=13014|format=|script-title=ru:Утро в сосновом лесу. 1889. ГТГ|publisher =Artclassic.edu.ru |author= |accessdate=2009-03-10|language=ru}}</ref> so the painting is now credited solely to Shishkin.
The ''Morning in a Pine Forest'' turned very popular, being reproduced on various items, including the "Clumsy Bear" chocolates by [[Krasny Oktyabr Open Joint-Stock Company|Krasny Oktyabr]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russiantable.com/store/Chocolate-%22Mishka-Kosolapy%22__146-14.html|title=Chocolate "Mishka Kosolapy"}}</ref> According to one poll, the painting is the second most popular in Russia behind ''Bogatyrs'' by [[Viktor Vasnetsov]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shishkin-art.ru/art.php?genre=10&id=269|format=|script-title=ru:Утро в сосновом лесу |publisher = Shishkin-art.ru|author= |accessdate=2009-03-10|language=ru}}</ref> Shishkin's similar paintings are the ''Forest in Spring'' (1884) and ''The Sestroretsk Forest'' (1896).
It is believed that Shishkin painted the pine trees near [[Narva-Jõesuu]] in [[Estonia]], where he often liked to rest in summers.<ref name="õhtuleht">{{cite news|last=Vahe|first=Urmas|title=Narva-Jõesuu saab taas Euroopa kaardile|url=http://www.ohtuleht.ee/200770|newspaper=[[Õhtuleht]]|date=2006-07-01|language=Estonian}}</ref>

<!-- EDIT BELOW THIS LINE --> {{Infobox artwork | title = Spring and autumn landscapes | image_file = Springandautumnlandscapes.JPG | caption = Spring and autumn landscapes by Hara Zaishō | painting_alignment = right | artist = Hara Zaishō | year = unknown | type = Ink and colours on silk | subject = seasonal landscapes | condition = on display | city = [[Toronto]] | museum = [[Royal Ontario Museum]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|40|4.07|N|79|23|43.81|W|region:CA}} <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = [[Royal Ontario Museum]] }}
'''Spring and autumn landscapes''' is a pair of seasonal paintings representing spring and autumn by Japanese artist Hara Zaishō (1813–1872). Both are currently part of the [[Royal Ontario Museum|Royal Ontario Museum's]] permanent collection, exhibited on Level 1 of the museum in the [[Prince Takamado]] Gallery of Japan.
==Hara Zaishō== Hara Zaishō (原在照) was the adopted son of Hara Zaimei (原在明), whom he succeeded as the third head of the [[Hara School]] of professional painters. Based in [[Kyoto]], the Hara School served from the late eighteenth through the early twentieth centuries as official artists to the [[Imperial Court in Kyoto|Imperial Court]]. Hara Zaishō contributed several pieces to the [[Kyoto Imperial Palace]] during its reconstruction following a fire in 1854.<ref>Imperial Household Agency</ref> The most famous of these is a cherry tree motif painted on sliding ''[[fusuma]]'' doors in the ''Sakura-no-ma'' (Cherry Blossom Room).<ref>Martin, 2002, p.307</ref> [[File:Hara Zaisho seal and signature.JPG|thumb|120px|border|left|alt=Hara Zaisho seal and signature|Hara Zaishō's seal and signature]] Zaishō’s career spanned the late [[Edo period|Edo]] (1603-1867) and early [[Meiji period|Meiji]] (1868-1912) periods, a time of great change within Japan as a result of its 1854 [[Bakumatsu|opening to the West]]. The Hara School was aligned with the [[Maruyama Ōkyo|Maruyama School]] of painters,<ref>Newboldt & Hanbury-Williams, 1908, p.116</ref> a movement founded in the late 18th century associated with western-influenced tendencies such as objective realism, unified perspective, shading and contouring.<ref>Screech, 2012, p.259</ref>
Hara Zaishō is also associated with the pseudonyms Kanran (観瀾) and Yūran (夕鸞).<ref>Kotobank</ref>
==Genre== [[File:Springlandscape1.JPG|thumb|120px|border|right|alt=A cherry tree in bloom grows on a mountain side.|''Spring landscape'']] These two paintings belong to the ''shiki-e'' genre: images depicting changing landscapes through the seasons. It was not uncommon for ''shiki-e'' to take the form of diptychs, with the entire year represented by images of spring and autumn.<ref>Screech, 2012, p.72</ref> That is the case with this pair of paintings as is indicated by the mirrored positions of the artist’s seal and signature on each scroll rather than both being in the bottom left corner as is usual on individual scrolls.<ref>Screech, 2012, p.71</ref> The pair is read from right to left, with spring preceding autumn.
These landscapes are [[ink wash painting|''sumi-e'']]—ink paintings—done on silk, a relatively expensive medium reflecting the status of the artist and patron.<ref>Screech, 2012, p.69</ref> They are mounted as ''kakejiku'' or ''[[kakemono]]'', vertical wall hangings. This type of painting would typically be hung in a ''[[tokonoma]]'' alcove, sometimes foregrounded by a seasonal flower arrangement and decorative incense burner.<ref>Screech, 2012, p.70</ref> ''[[Kakemono]]'' were usually hung low, as they were intended to be viewed while frontally seated at the distance of a ''[[tatami]]'' mat width (approximately 90 cm).<ref>Bowie, 2011, p.102</ref> Although ''kakejiku'' were objects of decoration, their lack of elaboration reflects their secondary purpose as objects to stimulate quiet contemplation. [[File:Autumnlandscape1.JPG|thumb|120px|left|alt=Hara Zaishō's Autumn landscape hanging scroll.|''Autumn landscape'']] This pair of paintings belongs to a period in Japanese art during which depictions of landscape were undergoing reconsideration. Faced with Japan’s emergence as a nation on the world stage, artists were moving away from classical Chinese conventions to develop a more nativized system of symbolic motifs,<ref>Baird, 2001, p.21</ref> and treatments of space.<ref>Singer, 1998, p.262</ref> The cherry blossoms in the spring image and the thatched roof in the autumn landscape tie Zaishō’s works to contemporary Japan rather than to ancient China.
==Style and content== ''Spring Landscape'' features a full moon shining above a solitary cherry tree in full bloom planted on the slope of a mountain. It retains the monochrome style with its refined Chinese associations,<ref>Screech, 2012, p.236</ref> but adds sparing use of colour in the slight pink of the [[cherry blossom]]s, symbolic of spring,<ref>Screech, 2012, p.42</ref> of transience and of [[Japan]] itself.<ref>Screech, 2012, p.43.</ref>
In ''Autumn Landscape'', Zaishō again depicts a mountain scene, an environment classically associated with the sacred.<ref>Sato, 1984, p.29</ref> Here, the slopes are flanked by pine trees, often invoked as symbols of longevity and steadfastness in counterpoint to the fleetingness of spring’s cherry blossoms.<ref>Baird, 2001, p.61</ref>
==Head artists of the Hara School== # Hara Zaichū (原在中) 1750 – 1837 # Hara Zaimei (原在明) 1778 – 1844 # Hara Zaishō (原在照) 1813 – 1872 # Hara Zaisen (原在泉) 1849 – 1916 # Hara Zaikan (原在寛) 1884 – 1957 # Hara Arinao (原在修) 1922 – unknown

{{Infobox Painting| image_file=Vädersoltavlan cropped.JPG | title=Vädersolstavlan | artist=[[Urban målare]], [[Jacob Elbfas]] | year=1535, 1636 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil-on-panel]] | height_metric=163 | width_metric=110 | metric_unit=cm | height_imperial=64 | width_imperial=43 | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Stockholm]] | museum=[[Storkyrkan]] }} '''''{{Audio|Vädersolstavlan.ogg|Vädersolstavlan}}''''' ([[Swedish language|Swedish]] for "The Sun Dog Painting") is an [[Oil painting|oil-on-panel]] [[painting]] depicting a [[Halo (optical phenomenon)|halo]] display, an [[Atmosphere|atmospheric]] [[optical phenomenon]], observed over [[Stockholm]] on April 20, 1535. It is named after the [[sun dog]]s ({{lang-sv|Vädersol}}, "Weather sun") appearing on the upper right part of the painting. While chiefly noted for being the oldest depiction of Stockholm in colour,{{cite news|url=http://svt.se/2.52851/1.99963/vadersolstavlan|title=Vädersolstavlan|date=2003-07-10|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=19 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427045118/http://svt.se/2.52851/1.99963/vadersolstavlan|archivedate=27 April 2011|df=}} it is arguably also the oldest Swedish landscape painting and the oldest depiction of sun dogs. The original painting, which was produced shortly after the event and traditionally attributed to [[Urban målare]] ("Urban [the] Painter"), is lost, and virtually nothing is known about it. However, a copy from 1636 by [[Jacob Heinrich Elbfas]] held in [[Storkyrkan]] in Stockholm is believed to be an accurate copy and was until recently erroneously thought to be the restored original. It was previously covered by layers of brownish varnish, and the image was hardly discernible until carefully restored and thoroughly documented in 1998–1999. The painting was produced during an important time in [[History of Sweden|Swedish history]]. The establishment of modern Sweden coincided with the introduction of [[Protestantism]] and the break-up with [[Denmark]] and the [[Kalmar Union]]. The painting was commissioned by the Swedish reformer [[Olaus Petri]], and the resulting controversies between him and King [[Gustav I of Sweden|Gustav Vasa]] and the historical context remained a well-kept secret for centuries. During the 20th century the painting became an icon for the [[history of Stockholm]] and it is now frequently displayed whenever the history of the city is commemorated. == Painting == The painting is divided into an upper part depicting the halo phenomenon viewed vertically and a lower part depicting the city as it must have appeared viewed from [[Södermalm]] in the late [[Middle Ages]]. The medieval urban conglomeration, today part of the old town [[Gamla stan]], is rendered using a [[bird's-eye view]]. The stone and brick buildings are densely packed below the [[Storkyrkan|church]] and [[Tre Kronor (castle)|castle]], which are rendered in a descriptive perspective (i.e., their size relates to their social status, rather than their actual dimensions). Scattered wooden structures appear on the surrounding rural ridges, today part of central Stockholm. Though the phenomenon is said to have occurred in the morning, the city is depicted in the evening with shadows facing east.Weidhagen-Hallerdt, ''Vädersolstavlan i Storkyrkan, historisk bakgrund'' The wooden panel measures 163 by 110 centimetres (64 by 43 inches) and is composed of five vertical deals (softwood planks) reinforced by two horizontal dovetail battens. The battens, together with the rough [[scrub plane]]d back, have effectively reduced warping to a minimum and the artwork is well preserved, with only insignificant fissures and attacks by insects.Rothlind, p 7 A [[dendrochronology|dendrochronological]] examination of the panel by doctor Peter Klein at the Institute für Holzbiologie in Hamburg determined that it is made of [[pine]] deals (''[[Scots Pine|Pinus silvestris]]''), the annual rings of which date from various periods ranging from the 1480s to around 1618. The painting can therefore date no further back than around 1620. This is consistent with the year 1636 given on the frame and mentioned in the parish accounts.Rothlind, pp 12-13 The [[dye]], covering a semi-transparent red-brownish bottom layer, is [[emulsion paint]] containing [[linseed oil]]. The painting was apparently painted detail by detail as no under-painting or preparatory sketches have been discovered, except for marks at the centres of the biggest circles indicating that [[compass (drafting)|compasses]] were used. As a result of this, the horizon tilts to the right; an [[x-ray]] analysis has shown that the painter tried to compensate for this tilt by altering various elements in the painting, including mountains added along the horizon and the gently leaning spires of the church and the castle. A narrow unpainted border has been left around the image.Rothlind, p 10 === Possible prototypes === [[File:Albrecht Altdorfer - Schlacht bei Issus (Alte Pinakothek, München) 2.jpg|thumb|''[[The Battle of Alexander at Issus]]'' by [[Albrecht Altdorfer]], 1529. ([[Alte Pinakothek]], [[Munich]].)]] No prototypes for the painting are known in Sweden, and while the painting is occasionally associated with the [[Danube school]], much about its stylistic and [[iconography|iconographic]] history remains to be investigated. A possible stylistic prototype is the illustrated Bible of [[Erhard Altdorfer]] (brother of the more famous [[Albrecht Altdorfer]]). Begun in 1530, it was inspired by the works of [[Lucas Cranach the Elder|Cranach]] and [[Albrecht Dürer|Dürer]], but also renewed the genre by combining commonplace details with an undertone of approaching disaster. In particular, Altdorfer's [[Apocalypse|apocalyptic]] illustrations for the [[Book of Revelation|Revelation to John]] deliver an evangelic message similar to that of the ''Vädersolstavlan''. Historical documents show that Olaus Petri, who commissioned the painting, combined biblical quotations related to the Apocalypse with the painting hanging in the church. Copies of Erhard Altdorfer's apocalyptic woodcuts may have been available in Stockholm through the German merchant Gorius Holste who lived by [[Järntorget (Stockholm)|Järntorget]] square and who was a friend of both Petri and [[Martin Luther]].Hermelin, pp 48-49 [[File:Albrecht Altdorfer 007.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Landscape with a realistic sky by Albrecht Altdorfer 1528. ([[Alte Pinakothek]].)]] In [[Albrecht Altdorfer]]'s ''[[The Battle of Alexander at Issus]]'', one of the most famous paintings produced by the Danube School, a composition similar to ''Vädersolstavlan'' renders the battle scene in a detailed landscape under a sky crowded with celestial symbols and messages. Just as in ''Vädersolstavlan'', the view is not depicted as it would really appear, but is rather a composite of factual elements as known by the artist. In ''The Battle of Alexander at Issus'' the eastern Mediterranean Sea, Africa, and the Nile River are represented as known from contemporary maps, while the knights and soldiers are dressed in 16th century armours and the battle is depicted as retold in sources from Antiquity. The frame suspended over the scene, a device which appears in many other [[German Renaissance]] battle scenes, is mirrored by the 17th century inscription in ''Vädersolstavlan''. In both paintings, Apocalyptic symbols in the sky are given a contemporary political significance. The realistically rendered sky, light, and clouds, in both paintings, are emblematic of the Danube School.Svanberg, pp 70-72 === 17th-century copy and modern restorations === {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; clear:right; margin:0 0 0.5em 1em;" | [[File:Vädersolstavlan.jpg|center|150px|Before and ...]] | [[File:Vädersoltavlan cropped.JPG|center|150px|... after restoration]] |- | colspan="2" | '''Above:''' The painting before (left) and after restoration (right).
'''Below:''' The 1632 inscription. |- | colspan="2" align="center" | ANNO DM 1535
VICESIMA DIE APRILIS VISUM EST IN CIVITATE STOC
