{{good article}} [[File:McCulloch Horatio Loch Lomond.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Horatio McCulloch]], ''Loch Lomond'', 1861 |alt=Painting of a lake with fading mountains in background and darker trees in foreground.]] '''Landscape painting in Scotland''' includes all forms of [[Landscape art|painting of landscapes]] in Scotland since its origins in the sixteenth century to the present day. The earliest examples of Scottish landscape painting are in the tradition of [[Scottish Renaissance painted ceilings|Scottish house decoration]] that arose in the sixteenth century. Often said to be the earliest surviving painted landscape created in Scotland is a depiction by the Flemish artist [[Alexander Keirincx]] undertaken for [[Charles I of England|Charles I]].
The [[Capriccio (art)|capriccios]] of Italian and Dutch landscapes undertaken as house decoration by James Norie and his sons in the eighteenth century brought the influence of French artists such as [[Claude Lorrain]] and [[Nicolas Poussin]]. Students of the Nories included [[Jacob More]] whose produced Claudian-inspired landscapes. This period saw a shift in attitudes to the Highlands and mountain landscapes to interpreting them as aesthetically pleasing exemplars of nature. Watercolours were pioneered in Scotland by [[Paul Sandby]] and [[Alexander Runciman]]. [[Alexander Nasmyth]] has been described as "the founder of the Scottish landscape tradition",<ref name=Chilvers2009p433>I. Chilvers, ed., ''The Oxford Dictionary of Art and Artists'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 4th edn., 2009), {{ISBN|0-19-953294-X}}, p. 433.</ref> and produced both urban landscapes and rural scenes that combine Claudian principles of an ideal landscape with the reality of Scottish topography. His students included major landscape painters of the early nineteenth century such as [[Andrew Wilson (artist)|Andrew Wilson]], the watercolourist [[Hugh William Williams]], John Thompson of Duddingston and probably the artists that would be most directly influenced by Nasmyth, John Knox. In the Victorian era, the tradition of Highland landscape painting was continued by figures such as [[Horatio McCulloch]], [[Joseph Farquharson]] and [[William McTaggart]], described as the "Scottish Impressionist". The fashion for coastal painting in the later nineteenth century led to the establishment of artist colonies in places such as [[Pittenweem]] and [[Crail]].
The first significant group of Scottish artists to emerge in the twentieth century were the [[Scottish Colourists]] in the 1920s. They were [[John Duncan Fergusson]], [[Francis Cadell (artist)|Francis Cadell]], [[Samuel Peploe]] and [[George Hunter (painter)|Leslie Hunter]], who placed an emphasis on colour above form. The group of artists connected with Edinburgh, most of whom had studied at [[Edinburgh College of Art]] during or soon after the First World War, became known as [[the Edinburgh School]]. They were influenced by French painters and the [[St. Ives School]] and their art was characterised by use of vivid and often non-naturalistic colour and the use of bold technique above form. Members included [[William George Gillies|William Gillies]], [[John Maxwell (artist)|John Maxwell]], [[William Crozier (Scottish artist)|William Crozier]] and [[William MacTaggart]]. William Johnstone was one of the artists most closely associated with the [[Scottish Renaissance]], an attempt to introduce modernism into art and to create a distinctive national art. [[Stanley Cursiter]] was influenced by the [[Celtic revival]], [[post-impressionism]] and [[futurism (art)|Futurism]]. Later in his career he became a major painter of the coastline of this native Orkney. Other artists strongly influenced by modernism included [[James McIntosh Patrick]] and [[Edward Baird (artist)|Edward Baird]], both of whom were influenced by surrealism and the work of [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder|Bruegel]].
In the post-war period the English-born [[Joan Eardley]] explored the landscapes of the [[Kincardineshire]] coast and created depictions of Glasgow tenements and children in the streets. Scottish artists that continued the tradition of landscape painting and joined the new generation of modernist artists of the highly influential [[St Ives School]] were [[Wilhelmina Barns-Graham]] and [[Margaret Mellis]]. Husband and wife Tom MacDonald and [[Bet Low]] with William Senior formed the [[Clyde Group]], aimed at promoting political art and producing industrial landscapes. [[John Bellany]] focused on the coastal communities of his birth. The coastal theme would also be pursued by artists such as Elizabeth Ogilvy, [[Joyce W. Cairns]] and Ian Stephen.
== Origins to the eighteenth century == {{See also|Scottish art in the eighteenth century}}[[File:KeirincxSetonPalace1638.jpg|thumb|[[Alexander Keirincx]], ''Seton Palace and the Forth Estuary'', c. 1639|alt=Painting of a far view of a Victorian palace estate.]] The earliest examples of Scottish landscape painting are in the tradition of [[Scottish Renaissance painted ceilings|Scottish house decoration]] for burgesses, lairds and lords, that arose after the [[Scottish Reformation|Reformation]] in the sixteenth century, partly as a response to the loss of religious patronage.<ref name=Dawson2007p290>J. E. A. Dawson, ''Scotland Re-Formed, 1488–1587'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-7486-1455-9}}, p. 290.</ref> Most were of heraldry, classical myths and allegory, but there were a number of painted landscape scenes.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9>A. Thomas, ''The Renaissance'', in T. M. Devine and J. Wormald, ''The Oxford Handbook of Modern Scottish History'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2012), {{ISBN|0-19-162433-0}}, pp. 198–9.</ref> These included the landscapes of four seasons in the ''[[Skelmorlie Aisle]]'' (1638) in the memorial chapel of the Montgomery family in [[Largs]] undertaken by James Stalker ([[Floruit|fl.]] 1632–38). They indicate an awareness of contemporaneous [[Dutch Golden Age painting#Landscapes and cityscapes|Dutch landscape painting]].<ref name=Macmillan1990pp58-61>D. Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'' (Mainstream, 1990), {{ISBN|1-85158-251-7}}, pp. 58–61.</ref> The Flemish artist [[Alexander Keirincx]] (1600–52) was active in England and Scotland where he undertook commissions for [[Charles I of England|Charles I]], mainly of royal castles in Northern England and Scotland. These included one showing [[Seton Palace|Seton House]] (1636–37) in its landscape,<ref name=Macmillan1990p67>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', p. 67.</ref> which is often said to be the earliest surviving painted landscape created in Scotland.<ref>J. Holloway and L. Errington, ''The Discovery of Scotland: the Appreciation of Scottish Scenery Through Two Centuries of Painting'' (Edinburgh: National Gallery of Scotland, 1978), p. 1.</ref> The theme of house decoration with landscapes was taken up in the eighteenth century by James Norie (1684–1757), who worked beside the architect [[William Adam (architect)|William Adam]] (1689–1748). Norie, with his sons James (1711–36) and Robert (d. 1766), painted the houses of the peerage with [[Capriccio (art)|capriccios]] or [[pastiche]]s of Italian and Dutch landscapes,<ref name=Baudino2011p153>I. Baudino, "Aesthetics and Mapping the British Identity in Painting", in A. Müller and I. Karremann, ed., ''Mediating Identities in Eighteenth-Century England: Public Negotiations, Literary Discourses, Topography'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2011), {{ISBN|1-4094-2618-1}}, p. 153.</ref> bringing to Scotland the influence of French artists such as [[Claude Lorrain]] and [[Nicolas Poussin]]. The Nories were also important figures in professionalisation of Scottish art and the development of art education.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp52-3>M. MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'' (London: Thames and Hudson, 2000), {{ISBN|0-500-20333-4}}, pp. 52–3.</ref>
[[File:JacobMoreNG 1897.jpg|thumb|left|[[Jacob More]], ''The Falls of Clyde: Corra Linn'', c. 1771|alt=Painting of a waterfall with small human figures.]] Probably a student of the Nories was Charles Steuart (fl. 1762–90), who produced a series of [[Perthshire]] landscapes for the Duke of Atholl at [[Blair Castle]], including ''The Black Lynn, Fall on the Brann'' (1766).<ref name=MacDonald2000pp52-3 /> Also among the students of the Nories was [[Jacob More]], who moved to Italy from 1773 and is chiefly known as a landscape painter who created Claudian-style, classically inspired landscapes.<ref name="Baudino2011p153" /> More's series of four paintings "Falls of Clyde" (1771–73), produced before his departure to Italy, have been described by art historian [[Duncan Macmillan (art historian)|Duncan Macmillan]] as treating the waterfalls as "a kind of natural national monument" and has been seen as an early work in developing a [[Romanticism in Scotland|romantic]] sensibility to the Scottish landscape.<ref name=Withers2001pp151-3 /> This period saw a shift in attitudes to the Highlands and mountain landscapes in general, from viewing them as hostile, empty regions occupied by a backwards and marginal people, to interpreting them as aesthetically pleasing exemplars of nature, occupied by rugged primitives, which were now depicted in a dramatic fashion.<ref name=Withers2001pp151-3>C. W. J. Withers, ''Geography, Science and National Identity: Scotland Since 1520'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001), {{ISBN|0-521-64202-7}}, pp. 151–3.</ref> Highly influential in this process was the Scottish philosopher [[Archibald Alison (author)|Archibald Alison]]'s ''Nature and Principles of Taste'' (1790), which widened the forms of landscape seen as appropriate for painting, placing an emphasis on their historical significance and emotional impact on the painter.<ref name=Macmillan1990p219>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', p. 219.</ref>
[[Paul Sandby]] (1731–1809), often considered the "father of British watercolour painting",<ref>M. Hargraves, ''Great British Watercolors: From the Paul Mellon Collection at the Yale Center for British Art'' (Yale University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-300-11658-6}}, p. 17.</ref> visited Scotland as part of the military survey that followed the [[1745 Jacobite rebellion]] and undertook a number of studies of Scottish scenes.<ref>R. Hewitt, ''Map Of A Nation: A Biography Of The Ordnance Survey'' (Granta Books, 2011), {{ISBN|1-84708-452-4}}.</ref> His abandonment of traditional pen and ink drawing, using washes of colour in order to paint directly in watercolours without pen outlines, opened the way for the creation of powerful Romantic landscapes.<ref>A. Wilton, ''The Great Age of British Watercolours: 1750–1880'' (Prestel Verlag GmbH & Company KG., 1997), {{ISBN|3-7913-1879-9}}.</ref> [[Alexander Runciman]] (1736–1785) was probably the first artist to paint Scottish landscapes in [[watercolour]]s in the more romantic style that was emerging towards the end of the eighteenth century.<ref>E. K. Waterhouse, ''Painting in Britain, 1530 to 1790'' (New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 5th edn., 1994), {{ISBN|0-300-05833-0}}, p. 293.</ref>
[[File:Alexander Nasmyth - Princes Street with the Commencement of the Building of the Royal Institution - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|[[Alexander Nasmyth]], ''Princes Street with the Commencement of the Building of the Royal Institution'', 1825 |alt=Painting of a busy street with on going building construction on right side.]] [[Alexander Nasmyth]] (1758–1840) trained in the Trustees Academy in Edinburgh under Runciman. He visited Italy, where he met with More, and worked in London, but returned to his native Edinburgh for most of his career. He produced work in a large range of forms, including his portrait of Romantic poet [[Robert Burns]], which depicts him against a dramatic Scottish background, but he is chiefly remembered for his landscapes and is described in the ''Oxford Dictionary of Art'' as "the founder of the Scottish landscape tradition".<ref name="Chilvers2009p433" /> He produced both urban landscapes, like ''Edinburgh from Caton Hill'' (1825), which put Edinburgh its geological context, and rural scenes such as ''Castle Huntly and The Tay'' (c. 1800). His works combined Claudian principles of an ideal landscape with the reality of Scottish topography.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp78-81>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 78–81.</ref>
== Nineteenth century == {{See also|Scottish art in the nineteenth century}} Nasmyth was also a highly influential teacher at the Trustee's Academy in Edinburgh. Among his students were painters who took the landscape tradition into the nineteenth century. They included [[Andrew Wilson (artist)|Andrew Wilson]] (1780–1840), who would become Master of the Academy in 1818, the watercolourist [[Hugh William Williams]] (1773–1829), clergyman and artist John Thompson of Duddingston (1778–1840) and probably the artist that would be most directly influenced by Nasmyth, John Knox (1778–1845).<ref name=MacDonald2000pp78-83>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 78–83.</ref> Williams' most famous work are interpretive versions of Greek landscapes, based on sketches taken on his travels there, among them ''The Temple of Poseidon, Cape Sunium'' (1828). His close friend John Thompson focused on a dark dramatic version of Scottish landscape, as in his most famous work ''Fast Castle from Below'' (1824).<ref name=Macmillan1990pp222-5>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', pp. 222–5.</ref> Knox directly linked Nasmyth's style with the Romantic literature of [[Walter Scott]].<ref>R. J. Hill, ''Picturing Scotland Through the Waverley Novels: Walter Scott and the Origins of the Victorian Illustrated Novel'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2010), {{ISBN|1-4094-7617-0}} , p. 104.</ref> Knox's ''Landscape with Tourists at Lock Katrine'' (c. 1820), was a commentary on the tourist trade that grew up in the [[Trossachs]] in the aftermath of the publication of Scott's poem ''[[The Lady of the Lake (poem)|The Lady of the Lake]]'' in 1810.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp82-3>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 82–83.</ref> He was also among the first artists to take a major interest in depicting the urban landscape of Glasgow.<ref>D. Kemp, ''The Pleasures and Treasures of Britain: A Discerning Traveller's Companion'' (Toronto: Dundurn, 1992), {{ISBN|1-55002-159-1}}, p. 401.</ref> Towards the end of his career he undertook panoramic works of the views from the top of [[Ben Lomond]], which played a part in opening up the Highlands as a spectacle that would be taken up by artists in the second half of the century.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp82-3 />
[[File:McTaggart, The Storm.jpg|thumb|left|[[William McTaggart]], ''The Storm'', 1890 |alt=Painting of a sea shore in a rough weather.]] In the Victorian era, the tradition of Highland landscape painting was continued by figures such as [[Horatio McCulloch]] (1806–67), [[Joseph Farquharson]] (1846–1935) and [[William McTaggart]] (1835–1910).<ref name=Szasz200p136>F. M. Szasz, ''Scots in the North American West, 1790–1917'' (Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000), {{ISBN|0-8061-3253-1}}, p. 136.</ref> McCulloch was a student of Knox.<ref name=MacDonald2000p104>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 104.</ref> His images of places including [[Glen Coe]], [[Loch Lomond]] and the [[Trossachs]], became parlour room panoramas that defined popular images of Scotland. This was helped by the Queen's declared affection for Scotland, signified by her adoption of [[Balmoral Castle|Balmoral]] as a royal retreat.<ref name=Billcliffe2009p27>R. Billcliffe, ''The Glasgow Boys'' (London: Frances Lincoln, 2009), {{ISBN|0-7112-2906-6}}, p. 27.</ref> The wildlife around Balmoral was immortalised by English painter [[Edwin Landseer]] (1802–73) in the much copied ''[[Monarch of the Glen (painting)|Monarch of the Glen]]'' (1851).<ref name=MacDonald2000p105>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 105.</ref> In this period a Scottish "grand tour" developed with large number of English artists, including [[J. M. W. Turner|Turner]], flocking to the Highlands to paint and draw.<ref name=Billcliffe2009p27 /> From the 1870s Farquharson was a major figure in interpreting Scottish landscapes, specialising in snowscapes and sheep, and using a mobile heated studio in order to capture the conditions from life.<ref name=Szasz200p136 /> In the same period McTaggart emerged as the leading Scottish landscape painter. He has been compared with [[John Constable]] and described as the "Scottish Impressionist", with free brushwork often depicting stormy seas and moving clouds.<ref name=Chilvers2009p376>Chilvers, ''The Oxford Dictionary of Art and Artists'', p. 376.</ref> The fashion for coastal painting in the later nineteenth century led to the establishment of artist colonies in places such as [[Pittenweem]] and [[Crail]] in Fife,<ref>P. Howard, ''Landscapes: the Artists' Vision'' (London: Taylor & Francis, 1991), {{ISBN|0-415-00775-5}}, p. 116.</ref> [[Cockburnspath]] in the Borders, [[Cambuskenneth]] near Stirling on the River Forth<ref>N. Lubbren, ''Rural Artists' Colonies in Europe: 1870–1910'' (Manchester University Press, 2001), {{ISBN|0-7190-5867-8}}, p. 165.</ref> and [[Kirkudbright]] in Dumfries and Galloway.<ref>P. Bourne, ''Kirkcudbright 100 Years of an Artists' Colony'' (Atelier Books, 2003), {{ISBN|1-873830-13-0}}.</ref> The [[Glasgow Boys]] emerged in the 1880s, rejecting much of the sentimentality of Scottish landscape painting and introducing elements of impressionism. Key figures included [[William York Macgregor|W. Y. Macgregor]] (1855–1923), [[James Guthrie (artist)|James Guthrie]] (1859–1930), [[John Lavery]] (1856–1941), [[George Henry (painter)|George Henry]] (1858–1943) and [[E. A. Walton]] (1860–1922).<ref>A. Gray, ''A History of Scotland: Modern times. Book five'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1989), {{ISBN|0-19-917063-0}}, p. 43.</ref>{{clear}}
== Twentieth century to today == {{See also|Art in modern Scotland}} [[File:Samuel Peploe, Iona, 1933.jpg|thumb|right|[[Samuel Peploe]], ''Ben More seen from Iona'', 1927 |alt=Painting of a blue water body with mountains in background.]] The first significant group of Scottish artists to emerge in the twentieth century were the [[Scottish Colourists]] in the 1920s. The name was later given to four artists who knew each other and exhibited together, but did not form a cohesive group. All had spent time in France between 1900 and 1914<ref name=Chilvers2009p575>Chilvers, ''The Oxford Dictionary of Art and Artists'', p. 575.</ref> and all looked for inspiration to Paris, particularly to the [[Fauvism|Fauvists]], such as [[Monet]], [[Matisse]] and [[Cézanne]], whose techniques they combined with the painting traditions of Scotland.<ref>{{Citation |author= |contribution= |date= |title=The Scottish Colourists |journal=Explore Art |editor= |edition= |isbn= |issn= |volume= |pages= |place= |publisher= |url=http://www.exploreart.co.uk/results.asp?SF1=art_style&ST1=The%20Scottish%20Colourists&SORT=sort_name |accessdate=12 November 2012 |authorlink= |archiveurl=http://www.exploreart.co.uk/results.asp?SF1=art_style&ST1=The%20Scottish%20Colourists&SORT=sort_name |archivedate=12 November 2012 }}</ref> They were [[John Duncan Fergusson]] (1874–1961), [[Francis Cadell (artist)|Francis Cadell]] (1883–1937), [[Samuel Peploe]] (1871–1935) and [[George Hunter (painter)|Leslie Hunter]] (1877–1931).<ref name=visit>{{Citation |author= |contribution= |date=|title=The Scottish Colourists |journal=Visit Scotland.com |editor= |edition= |isbn= |issn= |volume= |pages= |place= |publisher= |url=http://www.visitscotland.com/repository/library/932636/1000635/colourists |accessdate=7 May 2010 |authorlink= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080429020605/http://www.visitscotland.com/repository/library/932636/1000635/colourists |archivedate=29 April 2008}}</ref> They have been described as the first Scottish modern artists and were the major mechanism by which [[post-impressionism]] reached Scotland.<ref name=Chilvers2009p575 /> From 1912 Cadell visited [[Iona]] annually to paint and he was joined there by Peploe from 1920. They produced a number of works using the west-coast light and Iona landscape, particularly views of [[Ben More (Mull)|Ben More]], which both painted several times. [[John Duncan (painter)|John Duncan]], the arts and crafts artist, was still active in the early twentieth century and painted several landscapes similar in style to those of Cadell and Peploe.<ref name=MacDonald2000p162>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 162.</ref> Hunter used a vibrant palette to create notable paintings of the landscape around [[Balloch, Highland|Balloch]] on Loch Lomond.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp163-4>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 163–4.</ref> Leading architect [[Charles Rennie Mackintosh]] (1868–1928) abandoned architecture for painting after World War I and created a number of landscapes, particularly of southern France. He became associated with Fergusson, who pursued also experimental landscape in the inter-war years, many of which were around his home in the Highlands, like that at ''Craigcornash'' (c. 1925). The work of Mackintosh and Fergusson has similarities to that of [[David Young Cameron]] (1865–1945) who pursued the systematic painting of the Highlands in his later years.<ref name=MacDonald2000p178>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 178.</ref>
The group of artists connected with Edinburgh, most of whom had studied at [[Edinburgh College of Art]] during or soon after the First World War, became known as [[the Edinburgh School]].<ref name=EdinburghGalleriesEdinbrughSchool>[http://www.edinburghmuseums.org.uk/Venues/City-Art-Centre/Collections/Fine-Art/Scottish-Art-Movements/The-Edinburgh-School "The Edinburgh School"], Edinburgh Museums and Galleries, retrieved 10 April 2013.</ref> They were influenced by French painters and the [[St. Ives School]]<ref name=Macmillan2011>D. Macmillan, "Culture: modern times 1914–", in M. Lynch, ed., ''Oxford Companion to Scottish History'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2011), {{ISBN|0-19-969305-6}}, pp. 153–4.</ref> and their art was characterised by use of vivid and often non-naturalistic colour and the use of bold technique above form.<ref name=EdinburghGalleriesEdinbrughSchool /> Members included [[William George Gillies|William Gillies]] (1898–1973), who worked in both watercolours and oils around [[Ardnamurchan]] and [[Morar]] in the 1930s, [[John Maxwell (artist)|John Maxwell]] (1905–62) whose landscapes were influenced by mythological themes,<ref name=MacDonald2000pp182-3>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 182–3.</ref> [[William Crozier (Scottish artist)|William Crozier]] (1893–1930), whose landscapes were created with glowing colours and [[William MacTaggart]] (1903–81), grandson of the nineteenth-century artist, noted for his landscapes of East Lothian, France and Norway.<ref name=EdinburghGalleriesEdinbrughSchool /> His ''Celebration of Earth, Air, Fire and Water'' (1978) utilised the Borders' landscape in abstract form.<ref name=MacDonald2000p184>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 184.</ref>
[[File:WilliamCrozier, Edinburgh from Salisbury Crags.jpg|thumb|left|[[William Crozier (Scottish artist)|William Crozier]], ''Edinburgh from Salisbury Crags'', c. 1933 |alt=Painting of far view of a town with various building seen.]] William Johnstone (1897–1981) was one of the artists most closely associated with the [[Scottish Renaissance]], an attempt to introduce modernism into art and to create a distinctive national art. He studied cubism, surrealism and was introduced to new American art by his wife the sculptor Flora Macdonald. He moved towards [[Abstract art|abstraction]], attempting to utilise aspects of landscape, poetry and Celtic art. His most significant work, ''A Point in Time'' (1929–38), has been described by art historian Duncan Macmillan as "one of the most important Scottish pictures of the century and one of the most remarkable pictures by any British painter in the period".<ref>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', {{ISBN|0-500-20333-4}}, pp. 351–2.</ref><ref name=Gardiner2005p173>M. Gardiner, ''Modern Scottish Culture'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2005), {{ISBN|0-7486-2027-3}}, p. 173.</ref><ref>D. Macmillan, [http://www.scotsman.com/the-scotsman/scotland/review-painters-in-parallel-william-johnstone-william-gillies-1-2063707 "Review: Painters in Parallel: William Johnstone & William Gillies"], ''Scotsman.com'', 19 January 2012, retrieved 8 May 2012.</ref> [[Stanley Cursiter]] (1887–1976) was influenced by the [[Celtic revival]], post-impressionism and [[futurism (art)|Futurism]]. Later in his career he became a major painter of the coastline of this native Orkney.<ref name="MacDonald2000pp163-4" /><ref name=Gardiner2005p173 /> Other artists strongly influenced by modernism included [[James McIntosh Patrick]] (1907–98) and [[Edward Baird (artist)|Edward Baird]] (1904–49).<ref name=Gardiner2005p173 /> Both trained in Glasgow, but spent most of their careers in and around their respective native cities of Dundee and Montrose. Both were influenced by surrealism and the work of [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder|Bruegel]] and focused on landscape, as can be seen in McIntosh Patrick's ''Traquair House'' (1938) and more overtly in Baird's ''The Birth of Venus'' (1934).<ref>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 175–6.</ref>
In the post-war period the English-born [[Joan Eardley]] (1921–63) moved to Glasgow, where she was a graduate of the [[Glasgow School of Art]] and explored the landscapes of the [[Kincardineshire]] coast and created depictions of Glasgow tenements and children in the streets.<ref>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 191–2.</ref> Scottish artists that continued the tradition of landscape painting and joined the new generation of modernist artists of the highly influential St Ives School were [[Wilhelmina Barns-Graham]] (1912–2004) and [[Margaret Mellis]] (1914–2009).<ref name="MacDonald2000p193">MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 193.</ref> Polish [[Realism (arts)|realist]] [[Josef Herman]] (1911–2000) was resident in Glasgow between 1940 and 1943<ref name=Macmillan1990pp370-1>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', pp. 370–1.</ref> where he influenced husband and wife Tom MacDonald (1914–1985) and Bet Low (born 1924), who with painter William Senior (born 1927) formed the Clyde Group, aimed at promoting political art. Their work included industrial and urban landscapes such as MacDonald's ''Transport Depot'' (1944–45) and Bet Low's ''Blochairn Steelworks'' (c. 1946).<ref name=Macmillan1990pp370-1 /> [[John Bellany]] (born 1942), mainly focusing on the coastal communities of his birth, labelled "Scottish realism", was among the leading Scottish intellectuals from the 1960s.<ref>C. Richardson, ''Scottish Art Since 1960: Historical Reflections and Contemporary Overviews'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2011), {{ISBN|0-7546-6124-5}}, p. 58.</ref> Landscape has remained a major form in Scottish painting in the work of artists such as James Morrison (born 1932), Ian MacKenzie Smith (born 1935), Duncan Shanks (born 1937) and [[Barbara Rae]] (born 1943).<ref name=Macmillan1990p400>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', p. 400.</ref> The coastal theme would also be pursued by artists such as Elizabeth Ogilvy (born 1946), [[Joyce W. Cairns]] (born 1947) and Ian Stephen (born 1955).<ref name="MacDonald2000p193" />

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Jean Metzinger, 1907, Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatique, oil on canvas, 74 x 99 cm, Musée d’Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris.jpg | image_size=300px | title=Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques | other_language_1= | other_title_1= | artist=[[Jean Metzinger]] | year=c.1907 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=75.5 | width_metric=101 | height_imperial=29.7 | width_imperial= 39.8 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= | museum=[[Musée d’Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]] }}
'''''Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques''''' (''Colored Landscape with Aquatic Birds'') is an oil painting created circa 1907 by the French artist and theorist [[Jean Metzinger]]. ''Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques'' is a [[Proto-Cubism|Proto-Cubist]] work executed in a [[Divisionism|Post-Divisionist]] style with a unique [[Fauvism|Fauve]]-like palette. Metzinger's broad omnidirectional brushstrokes in the treatment of surfaces render homage to [[Paul Cézanne]], while the luscious subtropical imagery in the painting are an homage to [[Paul Gauguin]] and Metzinger's friend [[Henri Rousseau]].
''Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques'' is located at the [[Musée d’Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]].<ref>[http://www.mam.paris.fr/en/online-collections#/artwork/180000000001284 Jean Metzinger, ''Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques'', Musée d’Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris]</ref>
==Description== ''Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques'' is an oil painting on canvas in a horizontal format with dimensions 75.5 x 101 cm (29.7 by 39.8 in). The work represents three aquatic birds in an ambrosial Mediterranean landscape with semi-tropical vegetation, trees, a body of water, mountains and a sailboat in the background. The free and expressive brushstrokes of ''Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques''—as in ''Les Ibis'' and ''Le Flamant rose et le voilier'' of the same period—represent a loosening of the mosaic-like [[Divisionism|Divisionist]] technique that characterized Metzinger's work from 1905 to early 1907.<ref name="Joann Moser">Joann Moser, ''Jean Metzinger in Retrospect, Pre-Cubist works, 1904–1909'', The University of Iowa Museum of Art, J. Paul Getty Trust, University of Washington Press, 1985, pp. 34-42</ref>
By 1907 a select group of avant-garde artists in Paris were reevaluating their own work in relation to that of [[Paul Cézanne]]. A retrospective of Cézanne's paintings had been held at the [[Salon d'Automne]] of 1904. Current works were displayed at the 1905 and 1906 Salon d'Automne, followed by two commemorative retrospectives after his death in 1907. Metzinger's interest in the work of Cézanne suggests a means by which he made the transformation from Divisionism to Cubism.<ref name="Joann Moser" />
The lattices of squares or 'cubes' of paint employed throughout his Divisionist period have not been entirely abandoned, but pushed to another extreme. Where before brushstrokes had become increasingly larger and organized into groups of color, now they were larger still and elongated, seemingly blended together directly on the canvas (rather than on a palette). The treatment of color and composition is globally free, loose, expressive, and thus dynamic. There are no inert tones. Colors have retained their brilliance. As before, contrasting hues are placed side by side—resulting in rhythmic and optic vibrational effects.<ref name="Mittelmann">[http://jean-metzinger.blogspot.com.es/ Jean Metzinger: Divisionism, Cubism, Neoclassicism and Post-Cubism]</ref>
The lines and large strokes of color, like words, are treated autonomously—each possessing an abstract value independent of one another, yet together forming a coherent whole. The impulse toward abstraction becomes a primary quality of Metzinger's work of 1907. Though not without reference to the real world, Metzinger's treatment of the painted surface is meant to draw away from the outward appearance of nature. Imitation is vacated in order to concentrate upon the distillation of essential shapes and movements. These distilled forms were superior to nature because they partook of idea, and represented the dominance of the artist over the mere stuff of nature.<ref name="Robbins 1985">Daniel Robbins, ''Jean Metzinger: At the Center of Cubism'', 1985, in ''Jean Metzinger in Retrospect'', The University of Iowa Museum of Art</ref>
Complex in both composition and the rendering of color, the subject matter of ''Paysage coloré'', though clearly readable, is to a certain extent faceted and denaturalized. Its combination of painterly techniques, color and exoticism in its subject matter, sets it apart, resulting in a broader scope typically employed to define the Fauve movement.<ref name="Mittelmann" />
The spatial relationships between forms in the foreground and structures in the background are ambiguously flattened. Metzinger had already abandoned classical perspective for the most part since 1903, and now it had become entirely irrelevant.<ref name="Mittelmann" />
This composition was not only different from [[Paul Cézanne]], [[Georges Seurat]], [[Henri-Edmond Cross]], [[Paul Sérusier]], [[Maurice Denis]] and [[Odilon Redon]] and the other [[Neo-Impressionism|Neo-Impressionists]], [[Symbolism (art)|Symbolists]] and [[Nabis]], but different from [[Henri Matisse]], [[André Derain]], [[Othon Friesz]] and the other [[Fauvism|Fauves]]. Indeed, Metzinger, unlike others of his immediate circle, or peripheral entourage, would soon become one of the founders of Cubism—flanked between [[Pablo Picasso]] and [[Georges Braque]] on the one hand, [[Albert Gleizes]], [[Henri Le Fauconnier]], [[Robert Delaunay]], [[Fernand Léger]] on the other—and this painting was a step in that direction.<ref name="Mittelmann" />
Note: in ''Jean Metzinger in Retrospect'' (1985), the title, dimensions and provenance for this painting, n. 19 of the catalogue, are erroneously switched with n. 18, ''Le Flamant rose et le voilier'', (pages 40 and 41).<ref name="Joann Moser" />

[[File:Kaffeegesellschaft an der Alster mit Blick über Lombardsbrücke auf die Stadt - Hamburger Bilderuhr.JPG|thumb|400x400px| Bilderuhr mit Alsterpanorama (c.1830) ]] The '''''Picture clock with Alster Panorama''''' (''German: '''Bilderuhr mit Alsterpanorama''')'' also known as '''''Coffeeparty on the Alster with view to Lombardbridge over the city''''' is a [[picture clock]] or [[music box]] painting (Spieluhr-Gemälde) - an [[oil painting]] of a landscape scene with integrated [[mechanical clock]], [[Automaton|automata]], and music box that is in the collection of the [[Hamburg Museum]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hamburgmuseum.de/de/ausstellungen-highlights/bilderuhr-mit-alsterpanorama.htm|title=Bilderuhr mit Alsterpanorama|website=www.hamburgmuseum.de|publisher=Museum für Hamburgische Geschichte|language=German|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref> 74 cm x 89 cm in size, it was made between 1827 and 1830 by unknown group of artists and craftsmen<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/2063623/GER_280_005.html|title=Kaffeegesellschaft an der Alster mit Blick über Lombardsbrücke auf die Stadt (Uhrenbild - Bilderuhr)|website=www.europeana.eu|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref> and was restored by the museum and watchmaker Helmut Tüxen in 2012.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abendblatt.de/kultur-live/article206903563/Historische-Kunstschaetze-im-Hamburg-Museum.html|title=Historische Kunstschätze im Hamburg Museum|last=|first=|date=2016-01-09|website=www.abendblatt.de|publisher=[[Hamburger Abendblatt]]|language=German|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref> {{External media|video1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mkk7PPa4Cpk description of the subjects visible in the painting]|video2=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Su6kSxNcY94 description of the mechanical aspects and their restoration]}} The foreground of the painting shows a group of people drinking [[coffee]] in a park on the banks of the [[Außenalster]] lake. They are accompanied by musicians and children. The background shows the [[Lombardsbrücke]] (''Lombard Bridge'') and behind that a panorama of the city of [[Hamburg]]. From left-to-right the recognisable buildings are: * [[St. James' Church, Hamburg|St. James' Church]] (''Hauptkirche St. Jacobi'') * A [[windmill]] on the Alster [[glacis]] (one of the five that still existed on the [[Hamburg Wallring]] at that time)<ref name=":0" /> * The [[Hamburg workhouse]] ([[w:De:Werk- und Zuchthaus|Werk- und Zuchthaus]]) * [[St. Peter's Church, Hamburg|St Peter's church]] (''St. Petri'') * [[St. Catherine's Church, Hamburg|St. Catherine's Church]] (''St. Katharinen'') * [[St. Nicholas' Church, Hamburg|St. Nicholas' church]] (S''t.Nikolai'') These landmarks indicates that the scene is set on the Western bank of the Außenalster and oriented directly towards the South at approximately the location where the present day Straße Fontenay reaches the shoreline.<ref name=":0" /> St Peters', St. Nicholas', and the workhouse were all destroyed in the [[Great Fire of Hamburg]], 12–15 years after the painting was made. The wooden Lombard Bridge was replaced in the 1860s with the version known today and in 1953 the parallel [[Kennedy Bridge (Hamburg)|Kennedy Bridge]] (originally called the "New Lombardsbrücke") was built. It now obscures the Lombard Bridge from the painting's viewpoint.
== Mechanical elements == [[File:Lombardsbrücke um 1860, Photograph J.F. Lau.jpg|thumb|Photograph from 1860 showing the windmill, lake and original bridge, from approximately the same orientation as the painting]] The several church towers feature working clocks. Other mechanically operated elements of the scene are: * the windmill turning * two children playing [[cup-and-ball]] * a harpist's and a violinist's arms moving * various boats moving across the lake * foot and horse-borne traffic crossing the bridge * a fisherman's [[Fishing rod|rod]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image =Paul Klee Kamel in rhythmischer Baumlandschaft klein.jpg | image_size= | title= Camel (in rhythmic landscape with trees) | other_language_1=German | other_title_1=Kamel in rhythmischer Baumlandschaft | artist=[[Paul Klee]] | year=1920 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=48 | width_metric=42 | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Düsseldorf]] | museum=[[Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen]] }} '''''Camel (in rhythmic landscape with trees''''') [''German: '''Kamel (in rhythmischer baumlandschaft)'''''] is a painting by Swiss artist [[Paul Klee]] in the collection of the [[Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen]] in [[Düsseldorf]], Germany.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kunstsammlung.de/en/discover/collections/focuses/paul-klee.html|title=Paul Klee|date=|website=Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen|publisher=Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen|access-date=}} The painting is one of the first Klee did in oils and is typical of the artist's interest in colour theory, draughtsmanship and musicality. It is also one of many images in Western art to use camels as subject matter.{{Cite web|url=http://amor.cms.hu-berlin.de/~h1981d0z/pdf/2015-05-london/soas-london.pdf|title=The representation of the Camel in Western visual arts over 2000 years|last=Schwartz|first=H.J.|date=May 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} The composition of the painting is based on horizontal bands dotted with circular shapes. == Subject == Camels appear in manuscripts, mosaics, sculptures and paintings. For example, camels and horses appear in illustrations to the travel memoir of [[John Mandeville]] in the fourteenth century. [[Orientalism|Orientalist]] paintings of the nineteenth century include ones by artists such as [[Carl Haag]] ("Danger in the Desert", 1867) and [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]] ("Street Scene, Egypt", 1869). The memorial on the [[Victoria Embankment Gardens]] in London commemorates the [[Imperial Camel Corps Memorial|Imperial Camel Corps]] in sculpture. The year before, Klee had produced another camel painting in oils entitled "Two Camels and a donkey" (1919). "Camel in rhythmic landscape with trees" is considered one of a series that includes "Rythmic Tree Landcape".{{Cite book|title=Paul Klee: dialogue with nature|author1=Paul Klee |author2=Ernst-Gerhard Güse |author3=Richard Verdi |publisher=Prestel|year=1991|isbn=978-3-79131-141-8|location=Munich|pages=84}} Similar landscapes, such as "Small rhythmic landscape" were also created at this time.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theartwolf.com/landscapes/klee-small-rhythmic-landscape.htm|title=Small Rhythmic Landscape (c1920)|date=|website=theartwolf.com|publisher=|access-date=}} == Context and theory== {{Quote box |width = 20em |border = 1px |align = right |fontsize = 90% |salign = left |quote = '' I would like now to examine the dimensions of the object in a new light to try to show how it is that the artist frequently arrives at what appears to be such an arbitrary 'deformation' of natural forms.'' ''First, he does not attach such intense importance to natural form as do so many realist critics, because, for him, these final forms are not the real stuff of the process of natural creation. For he places more value on the powers which do the forming than on the final forms themselves.''
- Paul Klee }} This is the period when the artist was working and teaching at the [[Bauhaus]] in Weimar under the direction of [[Walter Gropius]]. The task of teaching caused Klee to meditate on the problems of art and as a result he produced what [[Herbert Read]] called "the most profound and illuminating statement of the aesthetic basis of the modern movement in art ever made by a practising artist".{{Cite book|title=Paul Klee on Modern Art|last=Klee|first=Paul|publisher=Faber and Faber|year=1958|isbn=|edition= English edition, with introduction by Herbert Read, translated by Paul Findlay. First published 1945 in German entitled "Uber die moderne Kunst"|location=London|page=|pages=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * Kudielka, Robert (2002) ''Paul Klee: the nature of creation, works 1914-1940,'' London: Hayward Gallery; Aldershot, Hants; Burlington, VT: Lund Humphries {{ISBN|0853318530}} * Schmalenbach, Werner (1986) ''Paul Klee: the Düsseldorf Collection'' [translated from the German by Michael Foster] Munich: Prestel-Verlag; New York, N.Y. {{ISBN|3791307940}} [[Category:1920 paintings]] [[Category:Bauhaus]] [[Category:Landscape paintings]]

{{Infobox artwork | title = Finnmark, Winter | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = Norwegian | other_title_1 = Finnmark, winter | other_language_2 = French | other_title_2 = Hiver horizon du Nord | image = Finnmark,_Winter.png | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | artist = Anna-Eva Bergman | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1966}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | type = metal foil on canvas | material = | subject = | height_metric = 150 <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = 300 | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | condition = | city = Antibes, France | museum = {{ILL|Fondation Hartung-Bergman|de}} | accession = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the coordinates (when known) of the artwork itself, i.e. not for the site, building, structure, etc where it is kept, otherwise leave blank (or omit): {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | owner = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''''Finnmark, Winter''''' (Norwegian: '''''Finnmark, winter''''') is a painting by Norwegian artist [[Anna-Eva Bergman]] in 1966.<ref name="europeana.eu"><cite class="book" id="CITEREFeuropeana.eu" style="font-style:normal">'''('''(en)''')'''  [http://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/2063612/NO_280_010.html Finnmark, Winter, Anna-Eva Bergman]. //   europeana.eu. Посетен на 25 април 2016 г.</cite></ref> The picture was made with metal foil on canvas<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fondationhartungbergman.fr/sitehhaeb/Anna-Eva-Bergman,36?lang=en|title=Anna-Eva Bergman - Foundation Hartung Bergman|website=www.fondationhartungbergman.fr|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref> and has dimensions of 150 x 300 cm.
The picture is part of the collection of the Fondation Hartung-Bergman in [[Antibes, France]].<ref name="europeana.eu"/>
==Background== Although Anna-Eva Bergman was Norwegian, she did most of her work in France, where she participated in numerous exhibitions until her death in 1987. Her principles in art grew from the line drawings she drew for books by herself and others. In her last forty years of production she opted for abstract paintings inspired by nature. Looking for new techniques, she used aluminum, silver and gold foil in her work.
Beginning in the 1950s, after a visit to the north of Norway, she began to paint its landscapes.
''Finnmark'' was created with aluminum foil applied to the fabric; a technique that gives a special light to this painting.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://Fondationhartungbergman.fr/wpaeb/oeuvres-3/ | accessdate= May 24, 2016 | language = French | title = Abba.Eva Bergman Oeuvres: L'oeuvre from 1952 to 1972 | publisher = Fondation Hartung Bergman }}</ref> It represents an arctic landscape in [[Finnmark]], Norway near the border with [[Russia]] in [[Murmansk]]. A strong contrast is expressed with light and dark areas in horizontal lines, representing the snow objects in the dark northern winter, the relationship between light and shadow in the landscape, creating a perspective effect that allows the viewer to look beyond the [[tundra]] of Finnmark.<ref name="europeana.eu"/>
== References == <references />

{{Infobox artwork | title = Road in Häme | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = Finnish | other_title_1 = Maantie Hämeessä | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image = Werner Holmberg Maantie Hämeessä (Helteinen kesäpäivä).JPG | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | artist = Werner Holmberg | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1860}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | medium = oil on canvas | material = | subject = | height_metric = 88 <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = 103.5 | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | condition = | city = [[Helsinki]] | museum = [[Ateneum]] | accession = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the coordinates (when known) of the artwork itself, i.e. not for the site, building, structure, etc where it is kept, otherwise leave blank (or omit): {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | owner = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''''Häme road''''' or '''''Hot summer day '''''is the most famous work of [[Werner Holmberg]] (1830–1860). It was painted in 1860.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/2063618/FI_280_002.html|title=Road in Häme (A Hot Summer Day)|website=www.europeana.eu|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> Though short, Holmberg's career helped develop Finnish landscape painting. He combined the traditional landscape painting techniques of the [[atelier]] with the modern outdoor ''en plein air'' landscape.
In the painting, a horse-drawn wagon is travelling along a rolling country road through a pine forest in [[Tavastia (electoral district)|Tavastia]]. The painting depicts the carriage from the rear on a hot day. Trees and vegetation are painted with accuracy and the perspective of the image from the fresh wheel marks in the dirt creates an impression of movement. One can almost smell the dust and pine needles under the wheels.
In 1853, Holmberg was the first Finnish artist to study in [[Düsseldorf]]. From the surviving sketches, it seems Holmberg's ''Road in Häme'' was probably painted in the [[Tampere]] region.

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Claude_Monet,_Saint-Georges_majeur_au_crépuscule.jpg | image_size=300px | title=San Giorgio Maggiore at Dusk | other_language_1=French | other_title_1=Saint-Georges Majeur au Crépuscule | other_language_2=Italian | other_title_2=San Giorgio Maggiore al crepuscolo | artist=[[Claude Monet]] | year=1908–1912 | medium=Oil on canvas | | height_metric=65.2 | width_metric=92.4 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=[[National Museum Cardiff]] of [[Cardiff]], Wales }}
'''''Saint-Georges majeur au crépuscule''''' (Eng: '''''Dusk in Venice''''', '''''San Giorgio Maggiore by Twilight'''''<ref name="NMW"></ref> or '''''Sunset in Venice''''') refers to an [[Impressionist]] painting by [[Claude Monet]], which exists in more than one version. Monet painted this subject as part of a series of views of the monastery-island of [[San Giorgio Maggiore]]. These were begun in 1908 when the 68-year-old artist made his only visit to [[Venice]].
==Version in Cardiff== One version of ''San Giorgio Maggiore at Dusk'' was acquired in Paris by the Welsh art collector [[Gwendoline Davies]]. She bequeathed it to the Art Gallery (now [[National Museum Cardiff]]) in [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]]. The painting is normally on display there.<ref name="NMW">{{cite web | url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/art/online/?action=show_item&item=1336 | title=San Giorgio Maggiore by Twilight | publisher=National Museum Wales ([[Welsh language|Welsh]]: Amgueddfa Cymru) | accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="Western">{{cite web | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-242800392.html | title=The Duck Pond That Grew into a 'French' Lake; How Did Claude Monet's Famous Paintings of Water Lilies Inspire Wales' Greatest Art-Collecting Sisters? | publisher=[[Western Mail (Wales)|''Western Mail'']] | author=Williams, Sally (2010)}} Retrieved 2014 via [[HighBeam Research]] (subscription required).</ref>
==Version in Japan== There is a version in the [[Bridgestone Museum of Art]]. [[File:Claude Monet - Twilight, Venice.jpg|thumbnail|Version owned by the Bridgestone Museum of Art in Tokyo.<ref name="Bridgestone">{{cite web | url=http://www.bridgestone-museum.gr.jp/en/collection/works/2/ | title=Twilight, Venice | publisher=Bridgestone Museum of Art | accessdate=2 February 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202112850/http://www.bridgestone-museum.gr.jp/en/collection/works/2/ | archivedate=2 February 2014 | df= }}</ref>]]
==''San Giorgio Maggiore al Crepuscolo'': Description of the painting== ''San Giorgio Maggiore al Crepuscolo'' is approximately two-by-three feet and painted in oil on canvas. It depicts mysterious buildings that seem to magically appear from the surrounding landscape, they almost seem to float in the background. The forms are gently inserted, though not enough to disguise their identity. The painting focuses on the [[Church of San Giorgio Maggiore]] with its bell tower rising to the top of the painting. To the right are the faintly visible domes of [[Santa Maria della Salute]] and the mouth of the [[Grand Canal (Venice)|Grand Canal]].
==Monet in Venice== Monet painted the church of San Giorgio Maggiore in six lighting conditions. With this varied approach, the paintings focused on the ‘nature of experience.’ He was particularly impressed by the Venetian sunsets, “these splendid sunsets which are unique in the world.” He had previously been inspired by other sunsets, such as those of [[Normandy]] (in ''[[Rouen Cathedral (Monet)|Rouen Cathedral]]'' and ''[[Haystacks (Monet)|Haystacks]]'', his series of the 1890s) and London ([[Houses of Parliament series (Monet)|''Houses of Parliament'']]). [[File:Isola di s giorgio maggiore pano.jpg|thumbnail|This photo separates the campanile and dome of San Giorgio Maggiore, as it is taken from nearer the Grand Canal than the place(s) where Monet's dusk paintings were observed. However, it offers a similar view-point to one of Monet's daytime San Giorgio paintings.<ref name=ima>[http://www.imamuseum.org/collections/artwork/church-san-giorgio-maggiore-venice-monet-claude The Church of San Giorgio Maggiore, Venice], Indianapolis Museum of Art.</ref>]]
===Viewpoints=== Monet and his wife [[Alice Hoschedé|Alice]] stayed at the [[Palazzo Barbaro]] for a couple of weeks, and then moved to the Hotel Britannia, where they stayed until December.<ref>The hotel's name has since changed to the Hotel Europa and Regina.[http://www.westineuropareginavenice.com/en/hotel-history]</ref> According to Mme. Monet, the Britannia had a view, "if such a thing were possible, even more beautiful than that of Palazzo Barbaro..." Monet painted looking out from this hotel, but not, it seems, in the case of this particular painting. Although the view from the hotel included the church of San Giorgio Maggiore, the painting appears to have been viewed from the waterfront known as the [[Riva degli Schiavoni]], where the island forms a focal point of the view.
Monet was reportedly reluctant to paint from the waterfront out of fear of conforming to other artists who were drawn to Venice, such as [[Renoir]] or [[Manet]].<ref>[http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/events/exhibitions/extramural/exhibitions/article/manet-ritorno-a-venezia-36755.html?tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=253&cHash=b2bbf4444d Manet. Ritorno a Venezia]. [[Musée d'Orsay]]</ref> San Giorgio Maggiore was a favorite subject for painters, including the proto-Impressionist [[J. M. W. Turner|Turner]].<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/turner-venice-san-giorgio-maggiore-early-morning-d15254 Venice: San Giorgio Maggiore - Early Morning 1819]</ref><ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/turner-venice-san-giorgio-maggiore-at-sunset-from-the-hotel-europa-d32165 Venice: San Giorgio Maggiore at Sunset, from the Hotel Europa 1840]. [[Tate]]</ref>
===Completion of the paintings in France=== Monet felt Venice was a city "too beautiful to be painted",<ref>[http://www.intermonet.com/venice/ Claude Monet in Venice]</ref> which may be why he returned with many paintings unfinished to [[Giverny]], his home in France.<ref name=ima></ref> However, he had already retreated from his earlier practice of painting from life, in front of the subject. He worked on the Venetian scenes at home and the death of his wife [[Alice Hoschedé|Alice]] in 1911 seems to have been a factor in their completion. In 1912 he held a successful exhibition ''Claude Monet Venise'' at the gallery [[Bernheim-Jeune]] in Paris.
== In popular culture ==
The painting became familiar in 1999 after its appearance in [[John McTiernan]]’s [[heist film]] [[The Thomas Crown Affair (1999 film)|''The Thomas Crown Affair'']]. In the film the picture is taken from the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. In fact, the Metropolitan does not own the painting, although they have another of Monet's Venetian scenes ''[[The Doge's Palace Seen from San Giorgio Maggiore (Claude Monet)|The Doge's Palace Seen from San Giorgio Maggiore]]''.
A Venetian painting by Monet was seized in July of 2016 by Swiss officials on behalf of U.S. authorities. It was described as being a painting of San Giorgio Maggiore. The owner, [[Jho Low]], [[1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal|embezzled funds]] from [[1Malaysia Development BHD.]], a government investment fund. He had purchased the painting for $35 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-the-1mdb-net-an-art-world-whale-1469091601|title=In the 1MDB Net, an Art-World Whale|last=Crow|first=Kelly|date=2016-07-21|last2=Letzing|first2=John|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-07-21}}</ref>
==See also== Other paintings from Monet´s Venetian series are to be seen in: *[[Bridgestone Museum of Art]] *[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]<ref name=ima></ref>
==References== {{reflist}} * Brownjohn, John and Stephan Koja and Galerie Osterreichische, ''Claude Monet''. New York: Prestel, 1996. * Koja, Stephan and Katja Miksovsky, ''Claude Monet: the Magician of Colour''. New York: Prestel, 1997. * National Museum Wales, "San Giorgio Maggiore by Twilight Breaking Dawn," [http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/art/online/?action=show_item&item=1336]. * Newcomb, Molly. "San Giorgio Maggiore at Dusk: Claude Monet." (2 April 2012) * Pissarro, Joachim. ''Monet and the Mediterranean'', New York: Rizzoli, 1997. * Tucker, Paul Hayes and George T.M. Shackleford and Mary Anne Stevens, ''Monet in the 20th Century''. New Haven: Museum of Fine Arts, 1998.
==External links== [http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/art/collections/daviessisters/ The Davies Sisters Collection]

[[File:Richard Freiherr von Drasche-Wartinberg Im tiefen Winter.jpg|300px|thumbnail| Richard von Wartinberg: ''In Deep Winter'']] The depiction of '''winter landscapes in [[Western art history|Western art]]''' begins in the 15th century. Wintry and snowy landscapes are not seen in early European painting since most of the subjects were religious. Painters avoided landscapes in general for the same reason. The first depictions of snow began to occur in the 15th and 16th centuries.''Earth Environments: Past, Present and Future'', by David Huddart & Tim Stott, p. 863 (quoted), 2010, John Wiley & Sons, {{ISBN|9780470749609}} [[Painting]]s that feature snow as a [[theme (arts)|theme]] are mostly [[landscapes]], even if some of these works involve [[religious]] or even [[fantasy]] landscapes. Most of these winter landscapes in art history are [[plein-air]] depictions of winter scenes, using the quality of gray winter light to create the special winter atmosphere. Depiction of snow in Europe is essentially a northern European theme.{{Citation | last = Kent | first = Neil | title = Soul of the North: a Social, Architectural and Cultural History of the Nordic Countries, 1700-1940 | publisher = Reaktion Books | location = London | year = 2004 | isbn = 1-86189-067-2 }} ==History== ===Between Renaissance and the eve of Romanticism=== [[File:Les Très Riches Heures du duc de Berry février.jpg|thumb|upright|''February'', attributed to [[Limbourg brothers|Paul Limbourg]], or the "Rustic painter", 1412 and 1416, [[Musée Condé]].]] Early European painters generally did not depict snow since most of their paintings were of religious subjects. The first artistic representations of snow came in the 15th and 16th centuries. Because frequent snowfall is a part of winter in northern European countries, depiction of snow in Europe began first in the northern European countries. Since the early 15th century, wintry scenes had been represented by artists in parts of large sculptural works on churches and even on a smaller scale in private devotional scripts such as the [[book of hours]], a devotional collection of texts, [[prayer]]s and [[psalm]]s. These were often [[illuminated manuscript]]s such as ''[[Labours of the Months]],'' a cycle of twelve paintings that illustrated the social life, the agricultural tasks, the weather, and the landscape for each month of the year. January and February were typically shown as snowy, as is ''February'' in the famous cycle of the ''[[Les Très Riches Heures du duc de Berry]]'', illustrated 1412–1416. Some snowy scenes also appear in a set of early 14th-century frescoes created by Master Wenceslas for the Bishop's Palace at Trento, showing people throwing snowballs at each other,Florian Heine, "The First Time: Innovations in Art", Bucher, Munich, 2007 at 33 and in a detail of [[Ambrogio Lorenzetti]]'s ''Effects of Good Government in the City and Countryside'' (1337–39).Philip McCouat, "The Emergence of the Winter Landscape", Journal of Art in Society,{{cite web|url=http://www.artinsociety.com/the-emergence-of-the-winter-landscape.html|title="The Emergence of the Winter Landscape",|publisher=www.artinsociety.com|accessdate=2014}}{{cite web|url=http://bjws.blogspot.se/2014/01/illuminated-manuscript-snow.html|title=illuminated-manuscript-snow|publisher=bjws.blogspot.se|accessdate=2014}} At that time, landscapes had not yet developed as a genre in art, which explains the scarcity of winter scenes in medieval painting. Snow was not depicted in art except where it had a context, such as in the winter months of calendars. During the Early [[Northern Renaissance]] and even more during the [[Dutch Golden Age]] in the 17th century, interest in landscape painting was increasing. The winter of 1564–1565 was said to be the longest and most severe for more than a hundred years – the beginning of a cold period in northern Europe now called the [[Little Ice Age]]. For the next 150 years, northern European winters were comparatively snowy and harsh. Crop failures, heavy snowfalls and advancing glaciers that consumed Alpine pastures and villages made the era a grim one for European peasants.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jan/07/brief-history-snow-britain-charlie-english|title=brief-history-snow-britain|publisher=/www.theguardian.com|accessdate=2014}} [[File:Pieter Bruegel the Elder - Hunters in the Snow (Winter) - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|275px|left|[[Pieter Bruegel the Elder]], ''The Hunters in the Snow'', 1565, oil on wood, [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]]]] It was early in the frigid winter of 1565 that Bruegel created ''[[The Hunters in the Snow]]'',{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/hunters-in-the-snow-winter/WgFmzFNNN74nUg?projectId=art-project|title=hunters-in-the-snow-winter|publisher=www.google.com|accessdate=2014}} regarded as the first true winter landscape painting. It was part of a series that illustrated the months, something thematically similar to the traditional Flemish [[book of hours|books of hours]] (e.g. the [[Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry]]).{{cite book|last=Stokstad, Cothren|first=Marilyn, Michael|title=Art History- Fourteenth to Seventeenth Century Art|year=2010}} In addition to the snowy ''Hunters'' (December–January), it included ''[[The Harvesters (painting)|The Harvesters]]'' (August). ''The Hunters'' depicts village life in a snowbound Flemish setting, showing not only hunters with pikes trudging off with their dogs to seek game, but also villagers gathered around a fire, frozen ponds with skaters, and houses and churches in the distance – all against a fanciful backdrop of snow-covered mountains. The series was commissioned in 1565 by a wealthy patron in Antwerp, [[Niclaes Jonghelinck]]. The paintings by Flemish artist [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder]] were on a larger scale than calendar paintings; they measured approximately three feet by five feet (0.9 by 1.5 meters).{{cite book|last=Foote|first=Timothy|title=The World of Bruegel|year=1968|publisher=Time-Life Library|location=Library of Congress}} Bruegel continued to depict snow in his paintings. He created the first nativity scene to include snow, ''[[The Adoration of the Magi]]''. He also started a vogue for [[Netherlandish]] winter painting. The popularity of landscapes in the Netherlands was in part a reflection of the virtual disappearance of religious painting in a now Protestant (Calvinist) society, which preferred non-religious themes such as [[still life]], [[genre painting]], and landscape painting. The tradition of painting landscapes continued well into the 19th century and developed into the [[Romantic painting|Romantic landscape]]. Between 1780 and 1820, following the initial vogue in the 16th century for Netherlandish winter landscapes, winter subjects again become popular. However, this time winter landscapes became popular in their own right, as the beginning of the Romantic movement created a new interest in the landscape. This new interest, combined with the decline of religious painting in the 18th and 19th centuries all over Europe, gave landscape painting for its own sake, not simply as a backdrop to a scene or a setting, a much greater and more prestigious place in 19th-century art than it had held earlier. {{Clear}} ===Romantic landscape painting=== [[File:Caspar David Friedrich - Winterlandschaft (London).jpg|thumbnail|288px| Caspar David Friedrich: ''Winter Landscape'' (c. 1811)]] Later, after a relatively warm period that coincided with the end of the 17th century [[Dutch Golden Age]], the European climate turned cool again, heading for a trough whose lowest point was in the second decade of the 19th century. In 1809, a series of major volcanic eruptions heralded the arrival of a particularly cold period as the clouds of ash partially blocked out the sun. The decade from 1810 to 1819 was the coldest in England since the 17th century. In 1812, the French [[Grande Armée]] was forced to retreat from Moscow by the advancing winter – known to the Russians as General Snow. These climactic events played a great part in the development of a new art genre, the winter landscape.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jan/07/brief-history-snow-britain-charlie-english] In the late 18th century, the growing Romantic movement intensified interest in landscape painting, including winter landscapes. Practitioners included the German artist [[Caspar David Friedrich]], who depicted remote and wild landscapes. Caspar David Friedrich was a romantic landscape painter, and was one of the first artists to portray winter landscapes as austere, forbidding and desolate. His winter scenes are solemn and still. They are often painted [[plein-air]], with the artist using the thin, gray light of winter to create an appropriate atmosphere and illustrate the effect of light reflected off snow. According to the art historian Hermann Beenken, Friedrich painted winter scenes in which "no man has yet set his foot". Although based on direct observation, his landscapes did not reproduce nature but were painted to create a dramatic effect, using nature as a mirror of human emotions. His aim was a reunion with the spiritual self through the contemplation of nature, paralleling Romanticism's validation of intense emotions such as apprehension, fear, horror, terror and awe. Awe in particular – experienced when confronting the [[Sublime (philosophy)|sublimity]] of untamed nature and its picturesque qualities – drew Friedrich's interest, as seen in his idealized portrayals of coasts, forests and craggy mountains. Friedrich created the notion of a landscape full of romantic feeling – ''die romantische Stimmungslandschaft''.[[Elizabeth Prettejohn|Prettejohn, Elizabeth]] (2005). ''Beauty & Art, 1750–2000''. Oxford: Oxford University Press, pp. 54–56. {{ISBN|0-19-280160-0}}.{{Citation|last=Beenken|first=Hermann|date=April 1938|title=Caspar David Friedrich|journal=[[The Burlington Magazine for Connoisseurs]]|volume=72|issue=421|pages=171–175|jstor=867281}} His works detail a wide range of geographical features, and he used the landscape as an expression of religious [[mysticism]].{{citation | title = Academic American Encyclopedia | publisher = Grolier | location = Danbury | year = 1989|page=332 | isbn = 0-7172-2024-9}} Along with other Romantic painters, Friedrich helped position [[landscape painting]] as a major genre within Western art. His style influenced his contemporary, the Norwegian [[Johan Christian Dahl]] (1788–1857), and, later, [[Arnold Böcklin]] (1827–1901) and many Russian painters, in particular [[Arkhip Kuindzhi]] (c. 1842–1910) and [[Ivan Shishkin]] (1832–98).{{Citation|last=Epstein|first=Suzanne Latt|title=The Relationship of the American Luminists to Caspar David Friedrich|publisher=Columbia University|location=New York|year=1964|oclc=23758262}} File:Caspar David Friedrich - Cairn in Snow - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Caspar David Friedrich]]: [[Cairn in Snow]] (1807) File:Winter Landscape by Caspar David Friedrich.jpg|Caspar David Friedrich: ''Winter Landscape'' (1811) File:Vinterlandskab ved Vordingborg.jpg|[[Johan Christian Dahl]]: ''Winter landscape at Vordingborg'' File:1876. Зима.jpg|[[Julius von Klever]]: ''Thaw on the Way'' File:Оттепель на дороге.jpg|Von Klever: ''Winter'' (1876) File:Walter Moras - Verschneite Waldlandschaft (02).jpg|[[Walter Moras]]: ''Snowy Forest Landscape'' File:Иван Федорович Шульце - Закат зимой.jpg|[[Ivan Choultsé]]: ''Winter Sunset'' (1920s) File:Ivan Constantinovich Aivazovsky - Little Russian Ox Cart in Winter.JPG|[[Ivan Aivazovsky]]: ''Little Russian Ox Cart'' The work of the 18th-century [[Düsseldorf School]] is characterized by finely detailed but still fanciful landscapes, often portraying religious or allegorical stories. Leading members of the Düsseldorf School advocated [[En plein air|plein-air]] painting and tended to use a [[Palette (painting)|palette]] of relatively subdued and muted colors. The Düsseldorf School grew out of, and was a part of, the [[Germany|German]] [[Romantic movement]]. Prominent members of the Düsselorf School included [[Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow]], [[Rudolf Koller]], [[Karl Friedrich Lessing]], [[Johann Wilhelm Schirmer]], [[Andreas Achenbach]], [[Hans Fredrik Gude]], [[Oswald Achenbach]] and [[Adolf Schrödter]].{{cite book|last=Humboldt|first=Wilhelm von|title=Gesammelte Schriften. 1. Abteilung: Werke. Band 6 1827-1835|year=1968|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-019258-2|pages=585|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CMJD-ToURyUC&pg=PA585|authorlink=Wilhelm von Humboldt|editor=Albert Leitzmann|accessdate=14 October 2014}}[[File:The Icebergs (Frederic Edwin Church).jpg|thumb|300px|''The Icebergs'' by [[Frederic Edwin Church]], (1861), [[Dallas Museum of Art]]]] French painters were slower to develop landscape painting, but from about the 1830s [[Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot]] and other artists of the [[Barbizon School]] established a French landscape tradition that in the 19th century would become the most influential in Europe. It is often assumed that [[plein-air]] painting started with the 19th-century [[Impressionism|Impressionists]], but in fact it was already common in the late 18th century when the members of the [[Hudson River School]] of American [[landscape art|landscape]] painters were already painting in plein-air.{{cite web|url=http://jamesgurney.com/interview.html|title=interview|publisher=jamesgurney.com|accessdate=2014}}[I really like the work before 1860 the best. People often assume that plein-air painting started with the Impressionists, but it's much older than that, going back to the late 18th Century. The Hudson River School painters, under the influence of Asher B. Durand, were the first to make a regular practice of it, and they often made more sensitive observations than later plein-air painters, because they weren't influenced by the notion of "art for art's sake." Art does not exist for its own sake. The purpose of art is not to make an aesthetically pleasing picture; it should be much more—to tell a story, reveal a character, convey an emotion, or express some truth about nature.]{{cite web|url=http://art-landscape.blogspot.se/2010/05/what-is-plein-air-painting.html|title=plein-air-painting|publisher=art-landscape.blogspot.se|accessdate=2014}} [[Frederic Edwin Church]], a central figure in the [[Hudson River School]], was known for painting large landscapes that he saw during his travels to the Arctic and Central and South America.{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/dallasmuseumofart/docs/dma_voyageoftheicebergs|title=Voyage of the Icebergs -online book|publisher=/issuu.com/dallasmuseumofart|accessdate=2014}}
''Plein-air painting, in its strictest sense, is the practice of painting landscape pictures out-of-doors; more loosely, the achievement of an intense impression of the open air (French: plein air) in a landscape painting. Until the time of the painters of the Barbizon school in mid-19th-century France, it was normal practice to execute rough sketches of landscape subjects in the open air and produce finished paintings in the studio. Part of this was a matter of convenience.{{cite web|url=http://global.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/464567/plein-air-painting|title=plein-air-painting|publisher=global.britannica.com|accessdate=}}''
===Impressionists=== [[File:Monet - Boulvard Saint Denis in Argenteuil im Winter.jpg|thumb|210px|Monet: ''Boulevard Saint Denis'' (1875)]] The Impressionists were the first artists who made plein-air painting a major genre. They painted outdoors and were interested in real-life subject matter. Their most evident preoccupation and interest was capturing the effect of light and weather at a particular moment – they often painted the same theme all over again in different light and different weather. The Impressionists were influenced in many of their subjects by Japanese woodblock prints. The themes of falling snow and figures with umbrellas in snow are frequent subjects in the [[ukiyo-e]] Japanese woodblock prints.{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/boulevard-saint-denis-argenteuil-in-winter-34290|title=boulevard-saint-denis-argenteuil-in-winter|publisher=www.mfa.org|accessdate=2014}}{{cite web|url=http://culturevulture.net/art-architecture/impressionists-in-winter/|title=impressionists-in-winter|publisher=culturevulture.net|accessdate=2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thecultureconcept.com/circle/monets-garden-melbourne-winter-masterpieces-exhibition|title=Monet’s Garden – Melbourne Winter Masterpieces Exhibition|publisher=www.thecultureconcept.com|accessdate=}}[During the latter half of the nineteenth century (1874 – 1886) many people found it difficult to cope with this new vision. It was all about capturing the moment, the joy of life and revealing many of its secrets or truths.] It is possible that a series of severe winters in France also contributed to an increase in the number of winter landscapes produced by Impressionists.{{harvnb|Rathbone|1999|p=22}}; {{harvnb|Sweeney|1999|pp=23–27}}; For the range of 63 major works produced from 1867–1893, see Moffett et al. 1999. Impressionist painters like [[Claude Monet]], [[Alfred Sisley]] and [[Camille Pissarro]] started painting large numbers of winter landscapes in which they experimented with the use of light and color to paint what they called the ''effets de neige'' (the effects of snow). Other painters who painted winter landscapes but less frequently were [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]], [[Gustave Caillebotte]] and [[Paul Gauguin]]. The French master [[Claude Monet]]'s first painting in his winter series of 140 paintings was ''A Cart on the Snowy Road at [[Honfleur]]'', which was followed by many other winter landscapes, including a long series with haystacks.{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/arts/artwork/claude-monet-paintings-1889-18948.htm|title=claude-monet-paintings-1889|publisher=entertainment.howstuffworks.com|accessdate=2014}} In the painting ''Boulevard Saint Denis'', Monet sought to catch the moment when the sun was hidden behind the clouds during a light snowfall. In ''[[The Magpie (Monet)|The Magpie]]'', Monet's largest and probably most widely known winter painting, he used blue-gray colors to depict shadows in the snow.{{cite web|url=http://www.claude-monet.com/the-magpie.jsp|title=the-magpie|publisher=www.claude-monet.com|accessdate=2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zucapaca.com/best-of-monet/claude-monet-1868-1869-the-magpie/|title=claude-monet-1868-1869-the-magpie|publisher=www.zucapaca.com|accessdate=}} The ''[[Impressionists in Winter]]'' was an exhibition organized around the theme ''Effets de Neige''.{{cite web|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1P3-39251539/snowy-landscapes|title=snowy-landscapes|publisher=/www.questia.com|accessdate=}} {{Clear}} File:Claude Monet - The Magpie - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Monet]]: ''The Magpie'' (1869) File:Gustave Caillebotte - Rooftops in the Snow (snow effect) - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Gustave Caillebotte|Caillebotte]]: '' Rooftops in the Snow (snow effect)'' (1875) File:Claude Monet (French - Wheatstacks, Snow Effect, Morning - Google Art Project.jpg|Monet: ''Wheatstacks, Snow Effect, Morning'' File:Paul Signac Boulevard de Clichy 1886.jpg|[[Signac]]: ''Boulevard de Clichy'' (1886) File:Neige-Bruges-1910.JPG|[[Georges Lebacq|Lebacq]]: ''Snow at Bruges'' (1910) File:Winter landscape Paul Gauguin.jpg|[[Gauguin]]: ''Winter Landscape'' (1879) File:Pierre-Auguste_Renoir_-_Patineurs.jpg|[[Pierre-Auguste Renoir|Renoir]]: ''[[Skaters in the Bois de Boulogne]]'' (1868) File:Auguste Renoir - Snow-covered Landscape - Google Art Project.jpg|Renoir: ''Snowy Landscape'' (1870-1875) ====Technique==== [[File:Claude Monet - Train in the Snow.jpg|thumb|210px|Monet: ''Train in the Snow'' (1875)]] It was the natural outdoor light that made the Impressionist's treatment of subjects different. They closely observed the various colors of light that were reflected from objects and captured those colors in their paintings. Since Impressionists painted in ''[[plein air]]'', the shadows reflected the light of the sky as it was reflected onto surfaces. Impressionists generally used vivid colors, with often thick application of paint, and real-life subject matter. The new technology of premixed paints in tin tubes aided the development of this style.http://yalepress.yale.edu/yupbooks/book.asp?isbn=0300050356 Previously, painters had made their own paints by grinding and mixing dry pigment powders with linseed oil.[http://www.phillipscollection.org/docs/education/lbp-kit_4.pdf Renoir and the Impressionist Process]. ''[[The Phillips Collection]]'', 2014 In the 1860s, many vivid synthetic pigments became commercially available such as [[cobalt blue]], [[viridian]], [[cadmium yellow]] and synthetic [[ultramarine blue]], as well as even newer colors such as [[cerulean blue]].Wallert, Arie; Hermens, Erma; Peek, Marja (1995). [https://books.google.com/books?id=pdFOAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA159&dq= ''Historical painting techniques, materials, and studio practice: preprints of a symposium, University of Leiden, the Netherlands, 26-29 June, 1995'']. [Marina Del Rey, Calif.]: Getty Conservation Institute. p. 159. {{ISBN|0892363223}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcimag.com/articles/83955-a-history-of-pigment-use-in-western-art-part-2|title=a-history-of-pigment-use-in-western-art-part-2|publisher=www.pcimag.com|accessdate=2014}} As a result, the Impressionists soon moved toward a brighter style of painting.{{cite book |author1=Stoner, J.H. |author2=Rushfield, R. |year=2013 |title=Conservation of Easel Paintings |publisher=Taylor & Francis |isbn=9781136000416 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1msM3h9mbaoC |page=177}} By the 1870s, [[Monet]], [[Renoir]], and [[Pissarro]] usually chose to paint on grounds of a light grey or beige colour, but some of the Impressionists had come to prefer white grounds.{{cite web|url=http://yalepress.yale.edu/yupbooks/book.asp?isbn=0300050356|title=Impressionists|publisher=/yalepress.yale.edu|accessdate=2014}} ==Gallery== {{Clear}}
